number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Do you like ARPG, awesome story and don't mind anime style? Well, then this is what you have been searching for your whole life.General Overview:As you start the game, you can select between playing Hugo and Yunica. Hugo is like an SMG, you can spam your basic attacks like crazy, but is slower than a slowpoke. And Yunica has oven mittens... oh, and an axe, and is quite mobile. After that you can choose your difficulty, whereas nightmare really is a nightmare, and easy for Hugo players (yes, I hate him and I can't play him).In this game, nightmare actually adds stuffs like attacks to the enemies, not just way more health and damage. Don't worry if you get stuck on a boss for 3+ hours in this mode.Upgrading your character is also possible. You get small crystals which are your ingame-coins. In Nightmare every crystal is 1 point worth. In every other difficulty, I think, the bigger crystals give way more points.The story:The goddesses are nowwhere to be found on Ys. It's your job to go to the surface and find them. Of course, they are in the giant Darm Tower, the lair of the evil guys. Depending on which character you play, the story changes a bit. You get a few different bosses and other cutscenes. Due to this, you want to play it again, just to see how everything plays out for each character.Overall, to leave it mostly spoilerfree: Each story had it's emotional part and was well thought-out.Gameplay:Hugo: Will make your hands hurt (You should map a key to autopress the shoot button 30x a second)Yunica: Solid Movement, good attack speed, fun to play and mittens.There are a lot of enemies. Some are just powered up versions of older enemies, others are completely new. Especially on Nightmare difficulty you have to be very carefully to choose how to deal with the enemy. Some are almost completely immun to your skills. Learing the patterns of your foes helps a great deal.Setting:You play in a huge tower. However, this doesn't mean the interior is all the same. Every time after one of the bigger bosses, the tower changes completely. One time you play with lava, the other time you play with sand and also mirrors!Unlockables:Yes, this game has unlockables. Once you complete the game with any character, you unlock something awesome and the boss rush mode. After you finish the game with every character, you get the arena mode and a shop. In the first you defeat enemies for points, which then can be exchanged for stuff in the latter one. The shop allows you to buy many things, like powered up spells, Hugo still sucks though.Soundtrack:Just listen to the trailer music. It's so awesome! The rest is also pretty good.Long story short:Buy it, so we get even more Ys on steam!

												The boss fights are generally better and it has the most fun to play as playable character in the series. But it is not as good as Oath. I think its because it feels more padded out. In order to unlock the true final boss you need to run through the same sets of levels in the same order twice as different characters, to unlock the bonus arena mode you have to run through the same game three times as different characters.The game is also a lot more wordy than Oath, with all three of the playable characters being unbearably whiny and having daddy issues. Music also took a step down from Oath, most of the non-boss music feels really limp and underwhelming.Though the boss fights are probably some of the best in the series, and a game that is worse than Oath is still a game worth buying. Just if you're going to buy only one of these, get Oath instead.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Fast paced, hack'n'slash, simple but fun RPG, that's how i describe this game!Around 10 hours of gameplay, but if you're like me, and enjoy exploring every inch of every level, then that'll be a little bit longer!! HehehYou get to control 1 of 3 characters (one of those you unlock when you finish the game), every one of 'em has a different story, but the main storyline is the same. Gameplay'wise, they have a basic attack and 3 different skills for their weapons and the game is really fast paced!! Boss fights are really cool! :)The game is a lil' bit hard at the beginning, but once you get used to it, things get a lot easier!Even tho' i say it's easy, it's not hard to find yourself some tougher enemies and get killed... So here's my tip: ALWAYS save your progression... Seriously!!It gets kinda annoying when you have been playing like 30+ minutes without saving the game and then, all of a sudden, a big pack of tougher and faster enemies apears and you die, losing those 30+ minutes of UNsaved gameplay! And the worst is, you'll have to do it all over again!!! So yeah... SAVE!This game is pretty cool, nice soundtrack, simple but good story, fast paced action and so on... The only problem with the game is that, most of your alies are kinda dull and easily forgettable! Only enemies and a few alies are pretty cool... But the other ones, you just finish the game and don't even remember their names!!Other than that, iz all gud! I recommend it! ;)

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Great game.  3 story characters to play as. (You need to unlock one). While they all tranverse the same levels they have a few differences in bosses but mostly story wise. They also each play differently. One weilds an axe, one is a mage, and the unlockable is a berserker.Spoiler: Toal, the unlockable chraracter, is the character with the canon storyline and true final boss. 	That said I felt the game had a great story and very worth its price, and with each character getting their own storyline it gives you a reason to play them all. Difficultly ranges from Very Easy to Nightmare. Upgradable skills/traits. You have to find your gear upgrades there is no shop to buy them from. Fear not since the gear upgrades are either in chest or given to you. No RNG luck based element to make you spend your days grinding instead of playing.Bosses have gimmicks but they also for the most part seem to follow a pattern. Though the gimmicks each boss have can be enough to prevent you from winning on your first encounter with them, and 2nd, maybe 3rd. This isn't a bad thing. It requires you to actually learn how the boss works if you want to beat them instead of just brute forcing it.That said I would just like to point out a couple of cons.1. Keyboard controls for the most part are fluent but on a certain boss they are a bit chunky.2. The same above applies to trying to fight flying enemies. I would suggest a gamepad if you have one.That said I am a keyboard player and still find it around 95% fluent. Perfectly acceptable.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												I picked this game up on sale after wanting a really good JRPG, or rather an action platformer. With a good combat system and a strong, responsive, gameplay methodology the game is a winner. You can complete the game inside of 10-20 hours depending on difficulty setting and past that there is a tonne of replay-ability through either doing it on harder modes or in playing the game again from another character's point of view (there are 2 characters to choose from at the start, a third being added at the end). It's well worth whatever price you pick it up for, though if you're not sure you'll like it (it grows on you), I would recommend at least snagging it on a sale. Basically, it's Zelda on the PC in 1080p, or rather a Zelda-esque game.Story: 8/10I played through the game on hard as 'Yunica Tovah', aka, Axe Girl. Being more of a agility-speed player it was my natural choice as I've never been that into mage characters, which is the other character model available as you start the game fresh. As a character Yunica is more or less your bumbling anime girl that has inner strength that expresses itself as impatience and immaturity, which naturally changes over time. I found her interesting - a little predictable at times, but as the plot progresses she does develop more facets and towards the end her angry side really is a welcome extension of her persona. As for the overall story and setting, I found them engaging and enjoyable. It's definitely a fantasy game firmly within in the anime genre, and if you like that then you'll love the game. Me, personally, I can take it or leave it, so for me the it would be the gameplay that would swing me on this.Gameplay: 9/10The gameplay is fantastic. Fluid, sharp, and precise. Everything I like and enjoy. As a new player to this type of game it only took a quick control re-mapping to something more western - WASD as apposed to ZXCV - and then I picked it up pretty quickly. The gameplay is great because you have a really well thought out of mix of trash mobs, mid-level, high-level, then boss-level type enemies. And towards the end-game they start mixing in conditions and aoe gravity pulls to really start tripping you up if you haven't mastered how to pick off certain enemies. And that's what the gameplay really is at heart: you get thrust into a new situation and you have to adapt to these new conditions pretty quickly through piecing together enemy attacks, patterns, strengths, and weaknesses. This is especially true of the boss fights, which were always thoroughly enjoyable, challenging, and at times, a little frustrating. All of which are designations of a good game.Difficulty is king here. If you have it on easy, you'll somewhat breeze through the game. Greater difficulties are just that in this game - it's not the western version of difficulty where 'Veteran' is what 'Easy' used to be in the late 90s, Nightmare literally means Hell.  I didn't give the gameplay 10/10 because of one reason: if you miss a chance to power up your weapon and you progress to the next stage, you'll suddenly hit a spike in difficulty. The same can be said if you don't more or less flatten the majority of enemies on contact (at first). So this can be a little infuriating as you suddenly can hit grind mode, unless you go back and find that missing upgrade. But, the good news is there's a transport system so it's not difficult at all. And, worse comes to worse, you can always use GameFAQs to trace your steps to that upgrade. Game design: 8/10This game is obviously Japanese in regards to design which naturally means that some inherent Western expectations aren't fulfilled. This takes the form of, or rather, a lack of:A nice looking menuThe ability to map controls inside the game (instead of inside the launcher only)The ability to skip cutscenes - even if you've already seen themThese are gripes that you get used to and they're only mildly annoying. If you're a JRPG fan, well, you're used to this kind of thing anyway. Level design throughout is interesting and never repetitive; effectively think of the game as like a Mario or Zelda game: you're always in one 'general area' but as you go progress through the levels/stages the scenary changes etc, such as Ice to Fire to Sand and so on. It's classical and is nice to go through again if I'm honest. These different stages bring with them different unique challenges that do require a bit of trial and error occasionally, which I feel is a good thing. Not enough games punish you for messing up, this one does punish you; but never in an unfair way. I like that method of design.Conclusion: 8.5/10Highly recommended if you want an old school experience in 1080p that is reminiscent of Zelda and old school Mario. It's a great game with solid gameplay elements and the story is engaging and interesting. If you're an anime fan then I'm certain you'll find worth in this game. If you're not an anime fan then your opinion will likely differ, maybe drastically so. But regardless, the gameplay is super strong and rewarding, so if you want a challenge then this is it. If you're in the unsure camp like I was, wait for a price reduction via sale then snap it up.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												I tend to be weary of japanese game ports. The PC gaming market is small over there, and it's common for developers to misunderstand PC expectations. Moreover, these types of games attract a passionate fanbase, who will often overlook technical flaws in their reviews.Good news: none of this applies to Ys Origin. The game runs at 60 frames per second without a hitch. Widescreen resolutions are properly supported. There is minimal letterboxing on menus, but devs have added additional graphics on the sides (rather than black bars), a nice touch. 7 hours in, I haven't been able to spot a single bug or glitch. Keyboard controls are implemented and the various tutorial screens actually reference these keys rather than gamepad prompts.As for the gameplay itself, other reviews give a good overview so there's hardly any need to expand on this. Personal recommandation, don't let your ego get in the way of a fun experience. As someone who finds the Dark Souls series' reputation for punishing difficulty to be largely overblown (and I love all Dark Souls games), Ys Origin's demo boss still handed my♥♥♥♥♥to me several times on Normal difficulty. Picking Easy for my real playthrough after buying the game, so far it has been appropriately challenging. Also worth noting leveling seems to be important in this game. Sometimes, getting two extra levels can be the difference between hitting a boss for 1 damage per hit or 10 damage per hit (those numbers might seem paltry either way, but when you think about it, the latter hits ten times harder). On Easy there hasn't been any need to grind experience so far.Overall, an excellent game. -75% discounts come and go on a regular basis, and at that price it's a steal if you're even remotely interested in the genre. Heck, I don't even like anime, but one can only stay grumpy for so long in the face of sheer fun.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Outside of an awful RTS spinoff on the DS Origin was my first real taste of the Ys series, and it was a taste so good I've continued to buy up all subsequent releases on PC. An action RPG comprising of three separate character journeys through a rather large and complex tower, featuring many natural obstacles and puzzles to overcome. The game is certainly challenging with a combat system that is easy to get used to and offers layers of options to your fighting. You're likely to die to each boss as you figure out the tactics, making it so satisfying when you do break through. There are few other games that have demanded so much attention and kept me hooked throughout the way that Origin has done.You can read a full review of this game here.[www.neoseeker.com]

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												Forget how Anime or cutesy it looks - this is one of the best action adventure platformers i've ever played. The combat is fast and fulfilling and the boss fights are incredibly fun and very challenging - you MUST like boss fights or else the gameplay won't have much appeal to you. The game kind of reminds me of Zelda in that you fight your way through differently themed stages/levels (dungeons/temples) with the sole objective of reaching the level's boss. Although don't go thinking that the game offers anything more than pure, fast-paced action and a lightish story.This is the first Ys game I've played and now I'm hooked. I can see why the Ys series has a dedicated following. On to play The Oath in Felghana next!

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
Ys Origin is built on what is possibly the best ARPG engine out there, featuring fast and tense combat with responsive controls that requires a little strategic thinking.  On top of that, the graphics manage to be impressively beautiful while retaining excellent system performance.  The plot's pretty good, too - about as straightforward as you'd expect in a game like this, but I think the character development carries it, and the fact that there are three slightly different versions of it (one of which is unlocked by clearing the game once, has you initially fighting against the other protagonists, and includes additional plot revelations) improves replayability.I do feel, though, like Falcom made a mistake with the difficulty levels and achievements - many mistakes, actually.  For starters, SP (points for buying ability upgrades) gain rates are tied to difficulty level, and some upgrades are so exorbitantly expensive that getting the related achievements is only feasible by playing through and farming on the lowest difficulty level, which is so easy as to be boring.  That's not the really crazy part, though.  The crazy part is the extra outfit for one of the characters - let me say that again: it's just an alternate sprite, and an achievement to go with it - that requires beating the game at least 6 times, including 3 on nightmare difficulty, plus spending a lot of time in Arena Mode.  Even if you just want to fight the unlockable optional boss, which I kinda do, you'll still have to do the 3 Nightmare runs and the grinding in Arena Mode.  Now, I do have to give Falcom credit for making the higher difficulty levels challenging in ways that are a little more creative than damage dealt/taken adjustments.  I already mentioned the SP gain rates (I think EXP is also affected to a lesser degree), and your special abilities have longer cooldowns, but the most noticeable difference is in the enemy AI: on higher difficulty levels, enemies will attack more frequently and aggressively, with bosses in particular saturating their lairs with hazards to your health, making the game not just more difficult, but also more exciting.  Unfortunately, though, your chances of surviving still come down to experience level.  A single level gain makes the difference between a boss fight you have absolutely no hope of winning and a boss fight you can probably clear with your character just barely still breathing if you practice a few times.  Upgrades, of course, help too.  And, remember, farming is slower on higher difficulties.  What this means is that a Nightmare playthrough is basically a long, tedious grindfest punctuated by occasional intense boss battles.  It doesn't help that all the dialogue, which ordinarily I'd appreciate, is all unskippable, and there's sometimes a lot of it immediately before a boss.  I had been planning on getting as close to 100% completion as I reasonably could (Caress of Steel?  Ha, ha, NO.), but having beating the game once with each of the three characters, including one Nightmare run, and cleared all but the last arena stage multiple times, it's gotten too repetitive, and I'm kinda sick of it now.  Uninstalling for my own sanity.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												This game is anime as hell, with horrible pacing, painfully awkward(ly translated?) writing, cringeworthy story, setting and characters that it shoves in your face in lengthy, unskippable conversations and cutscenes.You should still totally play it, because once all that stuff takes a break this game is an addictively fun simple brawler with a limited but very satisfying moveset, basic but enjoyable rpg systems and very challenging (depending on your level and difficulty), varied and interesting boss fights - all supported with a catchy soundtrack.Don't expect Dark Souls though: if any encounter is too rough - likely because you're underleveled - it usually can be trivialized by grinding a room full of enemies for 15-30 minutes to get a handful of levels over the boss. There's also easier difficulties to pick if you don't feel like "powerleveling".The regular playthrough is a very decent length already, and the game is designed for multiple playthroughs with different characters with different abilities and boss encounters, so if you enjoy the gameplay the game certainly delivers tons of it.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												J-Just.... THE EMERSION! A game that, to me, gave a really good bonding experience with the playable characters. Good difficulty and balance, yet still the possibility to easily gain some more fighting strength for tough fights. Not many games do, but this game gave me that empty feeling of sadness when it was over. I was forced to consider what just occured, and the meaning of it. And let me tell you, my conclusion wasn't a happy one. Knowing that your character was done and that you would never again experience the same thing is not very pleasant in this case. This is something I rarely see in the modern gaming genres. I want to mention a couple of things to those who have doubts about this game.It's a japanese game, so it does have some anime-esk cut-scenes and images. Yet, these occur very rarely, so do not be concerned if you think this would bother you (Though, seriously, why would it?). It's an old game, don't look for good graphics and such. Though, that's not what you primarily should be looking for in a game. The gameplay feels smooth and fast-paced, something that I thoroughly enjoyed. Characters that are extremely unique and different from one another. Discovering the plot feels utterly fantastic. Any time something plot-related occured in between my beat up sequences, I couldn't help but let my excitement lead me through the dialogues. Remember when I mentioned I felt really empty and sad about my character that I played? How I wasn't going to be able to see her anymore? Well, that happened with not only that one, but some NPCs as well. Definitely an achievement.Something more about difficulty. The game has 5 difficulty settings, two above and below normal. This makes it very suitable for people of all skill levels or interests. Keep in mind that you cannot change your difficulty throughout the game, yet this is also not necessary as you will always be able to beat the boss without exception because of the possibility to grind a level or two. Not once have I felt like a boss was truly overpowered. Rather, that I, myself, was underpowered. And that is something that's easy to fix. Now, something I really appreciate about this game is that you have 3 playable characters. One of which is unlocked by finishing the game with one of the other two. This is because the final one is the hardest one to play and to minimize sploilers for the other two. The reason for that is something you will have to find out for yourself. The last one also has the one true story, meaning, the heaviest plot. This gives the game amazing replayability. That is about the best I can give you. If this has not cleared things up for you regarding gameplay and such, I'd say you oughta simply look up a video and see for yourself. Try to minimize spoilers, however! So, to conclude my review, this game is heavily recommended by myself among others.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												Score: 8.5 / 10I haven't 100%'d the game yet, but I feel like I'm ready to review it after 120 hours of gameplay and 3 playthroughs on nightmare on all characters.I have played three games from the Ys series so far (Ys I & II, Origin and Felghana) and each one of them clearly shows the extreme effort Falcom and XSEED put into every aspect of the game: super smooth gameplay with solid mechanics and very few bugs or inconsistencies, pretty challenging difficulty, excellent performance, very flexible settings that support even 120hz and up monitors and modern resolutions, the portings are very compatible with modern OSes even though these games are from 2006 and earlier, the anime graphics and the artwork are sweet and pleasant (but not necessarily ultra detailed) and the soundtracks are masterpieces.In poor words, Falcom consistently does a great job in every aspect of the game and puts a great effort into making every detail perfect and solid. Both the engines of Ys I & II and Origin & Felghana have the perfect balance between graphics, performance and gameplay quality.I won't talk too much about the plot because I usually don't care about that stuff.Ys Origin is a prequel set 700 years before the events of Ys I & II and tells about the past of Ys, the twin goddesses, the black pearl and Solomon Shrine. Most of humanity fled to Solomon Shrine (which is on a floating island up in the sky), as the surface got taken over by demons. For the very first time we're not playing as Adol. We will be playing as one member of a group of adventurers (you can choose between 3 characters) sent to investigate on the disappearance of the twin goddesses, who seem to be inside the Darm tower.Pro / Cons:+ = pro- = con- no more "bump mechanics" from Ys I & II. In my opinion, this combat system was unique and kinda set Ys apart from other action RPG's, also it made boss fights a bit more challenging. Ys Origin & other newer Ys games ditched that system for more generic hack n slash mechanics + magic which is okay but nothing special.- the game takes place entirely inside of the Darm Tower, so there is not that much variety environment-wise.- while Ys I had very short but extremely fast & challenging boss fights (except for a few bosses with bugged AI's), the boss fights on Ys Origin are slow and long, and since the bosses heavily rely on RNG, defeating a boss on Nightmare difficulty is 50% skill 50% luck unless you overlevel to fight that luck factor. Either way, there is too much luck involved in boss fights, and sometimes it can become frustrating even if you can actually beat the boss 100% of the times. This also makes boss rush / time attack extremely tedious and frustrating especially on Nightmare where you will be barely equipped to beat the boss. In Ys I & II, on the other hand, the boss fights were 100% skill based and used nearly no RNG-based attacks, but they were so challenging that you had to practice for a bit to master them even if you memorized them, so the results of the boss fights scaled directly with the player's skill.- there is a lot more grinding required, too much for my tastes. Leveling up for bosses takes much longer and filling the monster book is now random instead of having to kill each mob 31 times.- the dialogue can be sped up but not skipped. this can be frustrating when playing through the game multiple times.- the save system does not allow you anymore to save anywhere - you can teleport to save points, but you will have to save there so that adds some useless backtracking when saving before dangerous situations. On the other hand, the teleport system is handy to quickly teleport to every area of the game, but a system like the wings in Ys II would've been enough.- Alt + F4'ing the game has a chance to corrupt your monster book+ a playthrough takes about 10 hours if you kill all of the bosses first try and 20-30+ hours if you take a few tries to beat each boss, which is pretty optimal for multiple playthroughs or speedruns.+ amazing soundtrack with lots of remasters of the original darm tower musics in Ys I+ lots of references to Ys I & II: remastered bosses, lots of monsters in common, lots of remastered music, some key items in common and the plot is nicely linked and properly explains all of the backstory behind Ys I.+ very high replay value: each character sees the story from an entirely different perspective, will encounter slightly different bosses and each character's boss fight is balanced differently. There's also an arena mode where you will be able to fight monsters from different areas of the game to gain SP you can use to unlock alternative versions of the characters and other bonus content, including a secret boss. Completing all of the achievements will take up to 6 playthroughs or more. There's also the usual monster book you have to fill by grinding all of the monsters in the game (some are missable), an upgrade system for your characters where you can spend SP earned from mobs, and various Roo's hidden around the game that will give you missable upgrades if you feed them Roda Fruits (also hidden & missable).+ the achievements where you have to beat two "unbeatable" boss that you normally have to lose to are pretty interesting challenges even though they're heavily rng based+ retrying bosses doesn't make you go through the dialogue all over again+ perfect support for the 360 joypad and ps3 joypad + ds3 tool+ the engine has a minimum guaranteed performance: for example, if there's too many effects on screen some of them will not display, that way there is always a guaranteed minimum framerate even in the worst scenario.+ the bosses partially retain the "bullet hell on foot" feel that Ys I & II had.It's not a masterpiece like Ys I & II, but it's an excellent game like most Falcom games and it's certainly worth the price. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2013
												Ys Origin from Nihon Falcom is a Japanese take on the ARPG genre, so it's a JARPG I guess. I didn't really know what to expect when I started playing it but I have to say I was pleasantly surprised. The combat is solid and the graphics are charming.  Although you aren't given free reign to upgrade your character like a Western ARPG you level up as you kill monsters which strengthens your stats and you also gain SP by killing monsters which you can use to purchase upgrades for your character to increase passive stats such as Mana Cost for spells. Grinding is also well done in this game, if you kill the monsters as you advance through the game your character will be strong enough to defeat the bosses; however, if you're having trouble with a particular enemy you can grind up to increase your stats if you wish. Speaking of bosses, it was the best part about the game. The boss fights are well designed, challenging, but also fair. It's kind of a "find the pattern" type of deal, but there's a lot of skill involved in defeating the many bosses in the game. It had a Demon's Souls type of feel for the boss battles but the rest of the game had a Zelda-esque feel to it. The bosses were so fun I thought to myself while playing, "it would be awesome if this game had a boss rush mode." Little did I know, it does! It unlocks after you beat the game.While I enjoyed the game a lot, it did have a few problems. The game is linear, with you having to find a key or item to get to the next area and there isn't an open world as you're just going up a tower. That's not to say the environments aren't varied, as they are, it just means there isn't much exploring to do. There's also a bit too much backtracking for my taste, but it wasn't too excessive. The music is pretty low quality and repetative and the control settings aren't adjustable in-game (you have to use a separately loaded launcher) so if you don't have your controller settings set properly you have to exit the entire game to get it right; other than that the controller support in the game is quite good. There are three playable characters (one of which is unlockable), each of which gives you a different point of view on the narrative. The unlockable character is actually a demon as well, so you get the antagonist's point of view on the story which I found quite cool. The story itself is rather tropey, but still was a little more adult than other JRPGs I have played (it has swear words and death) which I enjoyed. The game loads and exits in a snap, which is also a plus.Pros:GameplayStoryline (multiple perspectives)3 Characters that play quite differently"Grinding" done well for a JRPGBoss FightsUnlockables and Bonus Modes (with leaderboard support!)Excellent ReplayabilityCons:Music/AudioBacktrackingLinearityI really enjoyed this Japanese take on the ARPG genre. If you enjoy killer boss fights I'd recommend it for you. There's also a boss rush mode which is amazing for this game and many other unlockables to keep your interest in the game after you've beaten it. The three available characters all play differently and show you a different perspective on the events of the story and I'm really looking forward to coming back and playing this game again once I've finished the other games in my collection. There are a few negative aspects of Ys Origin (I really disliked the audio engineering) but they don't overbearingly detract from the fun I had with this game. A-NOTE: I did play Ys Oath in Felghana and I have to say I wasn't as impressed with that game as I was with this one.  The boss battles weren't as epic, grinding felt more necessary, the music was better (but still repetetive), and basically everything that was good about that game is in Origin, but there's a lot missing.  The protagonist is also silent (which hasn't been cool since Freeman did it), and there's only one playable character.  I would NOT recommend Oath, but Origin is great.  If you want more of the same gameplay, play the other characters on Origin - skip Oath unless you REALLY love the series.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Maybe my biggest surprise / gut purchase ever. Ys is one of those darling series where everyone seems to want to tell you how good it is yet few people have played. While I won't say it's become one of my favorite series, it's become one I've begun to follow, and it along with Trails in the Sky has put Falcom on my mental map when it comes to video games.Ys, pronounced something like "ease" with only the first letter capitalized and no apostrophe, is basically an action jrpg without random battles or a heavy story emphasis. There's a moderate amount of text dialogue but it's interesting enough and no voice acting to drag it down. Ys Origin is essentially a far prequel to the events of Ys I and II, also available on Steam but significantly more dated. You are given two choices of characters. Yunica provides gameplay more similar to that of series protagonist Adol, specilizing in close combat fighting. Hugo seems to be a more experimental playstyle for the series, focusing on long range magic attacks.I strongly suggest Yunica to be your first playthrough character for the game. Her playstyle is simply exceedingly more engaging than Hugo, who simply becomes a button spam unless playing at one of the more difficult settings. Luckily to unlock the third character you only need to beat the game as one of these two, which is nice if you want to experience the full canon story of the third character without slogging through a Hugo playthrough. Though you may find you don't mind and will want to play his story anyways.Ys Origin is a brief experience, which is good considering that if you want to see everything you have to play the game a few times. It also allows for replays and taking on higher difficulties if you find you truly want to master the battle system. While the common enemies may not offer much lateral thought in how you tackle them, the frequent and varied boss encounters are quite a relative spectacle and there's no re-skinning or re-hashing to be seen here. All of them are tackled in a different way.There is a plethora of music selections for each section of the tower. The whole soundtrack is great an I often found myself humming some of the more memorable tracks. There's also good variety, so finding a few floors with a theme you don't really care for is offset by knowing that a new track is just around the corner.Definietly consider it if you are looking for a unique jrpg without the bloat that SE or someone like NamcoBandai puts out these days.8.5/10

Posted: September 28, 2013
												Ys Origin is a fantastic and surprising game. At the start it appears to be a fairly standard JRPG-esq story with the memorable and challenging hack and slash gameplay Ys is known for, but as you play through the game multiple times with each of the characters, what was first a simple, borderline cliche, if well executed tale becomes far more memorable, complex, and touching. No other game I've seen tells a story like it, and its a damn good story to boot. With memorable characters and story, fantastic gameplay, and a mindblowing soundtrack, there is little reason not to get Ys Origin as soon as you can.

												It's what the Zelda games should be, very nice Action RPG gameplay. Check out the demo if you're not convinced by the screenshots and videos, then buying the game will be the Ys-iest decision you'll ever make. Also check out Ys: Oath, very similar.

Posted: January 5, 2014
												My score: 9.5/10I have yet to find anything really wrong with this game.  It plays very much like an old-school RPG but with action elements instead of turn-based combat.  You're slashing, smashing, and magicking your way through a 20-something story tower full of demons.  I don't want to go much into the story because that's half of what makes this game so brilliant.  I haven't played a game with such a great story in a very long time.  Finish this game through to the end as well, because there's a bunch of unlockables (time-attack and an arena battle mode, to name a couple... naming more would be spoilers).  The replay value is pretty good but if you're going for a 100% completion it could take a long while.Gameplay-wise, it has a few quirks to get used to, and it'll take some time, but once you've got it down it's pretty easy.  The boss battles are INSANE, and there are a LOT.  If you're a fan of great boss fights, you'll love this game.  Each difficulty brings a new attack pattern, etc. to the bosses in addition to basically oneshotting you if you're not properly leveled/geared.The only qualm I can see that some people might have is that, like I mentioned earlier, if you aren't properly leveled you're going to have a rough time in certain areas of the game (bosses in particular).  The good news is that you'll catch on pretty quick.  The bad news is that you might have to sit there grinding enemies for a while - which isn't too bad, but you have to make sure you save often just in case.TLDR: Fantastic story, quirky controls, fantastic boss fights, lots of unlockables and decent replay value.  Pick this game up and if you want more of the story, pick up Ys I & II as well as Oath in Felghana.  All four games are worth it, trust me.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												This game is what revived ARPGs for me. Fast paced combat, enough story to keep you mildly invested, and multiple characters to help fit more than one type of playstle. Ys Origin has many [noticible] flaws and successes, most of which make it the game it is today.Pros: 3 Playable characters- We have your battle axe wielding berserker-style teenager, your snooty mage, and your "Git gud and unlock me" Character. Each one plays differently because of movement, magic skills, or how well they can manage themselves in, what I like to call, "crisis" situations (instances where you end up in a terrible spot and thinking/reacting fast is your only means of survival".Jumping- FINALLY, A GAME WHERE I CAN PLAY AN RPG, FIGHT IN REAL TIME, AND JUMP!!!! Moving in 3 dimensions makes platforming puzzles and combat reach another level of challenging.Puzzles- Puzzles are NEVER stupidly difficult and one particular puzzle can actually be solved without getting a "mandatory" upgrade nearby as 2 of the 3 characters. Puzzles are more meant to keep you from "completely" blitzing through the game.Story- Story is spaced out enough that it will never wholely interrupt your climb through the tower, but will still be there to keep you interestedBoss Fights- Probably the crowning achievement of Ys games, the boss fights will almost ALWAYS let you have a ton of fun on any difficulty (Yes, even people like me who are frustrated on higher difficulties still enjoy Nightmare mode/Inferno mode for Oath in Felghana). The fact that most of them keep the same pace, or even speed up a bit near the end of the fight, keeps the adrenaline pumping and makes victories that much sweeter.Difficulty select- You can't change once you start...but at the beginning there are multiple difficulties for the casual/hardcore masochist in all of us. Very Easy mode for the people who just want to beat the game, all the way up to Nightmare for the people who want to be challenged/punished for slightly better unlockable rewards.Music- FOR THE LOVE OF EVERYTHING SACRED AND DEMONIC IN ALL WORLDS, THIS MUSIC IS AMAZING :L I am a SLAVE to the soundtracks in Ys games! Fanboying aside....we DO have many memorable tracks and a few that may put you to sleep (I'm looking at you 2nd sector >.<) but the tracks are all VERY good standalone....just not always for extended periods of time. The BGM will be the same for the ENTIRE time you are in a sector/until you enter a boss area, so get used to them.Cons- Combat playstyles- Each character can only really play one way...turning trash mob combat into tedium when you are a few levels shy of doing any real damage to enemies. Trash mobs WILL eventually turn into beat-em up sections if you need to go level grinding for any reason.Level to Damage scaling- You will get new armor and be able to upgrade your weapon as you play through the game but at the same time your level is just as dependant on your damage. If you are even 2 levels shy of where you "should be" you will do little to no damage. You will literally get a small damage/defense spike around certain levels just so you keep up, a pattern present in Ys: Oath in Felghana as well. The same applies to having a weapon too low level. I was at the 3rd boss of the game as the 1st playable character and I noticed I could barely do 2 damage to the guy. Turns out, I missed an upgrade partway through the tower section I was in; because the MOMENT I got it the boss was taking normalized damage again. Upgrade (as a result) are NOT optional, which may kill the game for you if you are playing on Hard/Nightmare and you are going in blind. Glitches- The game is relatively glitch-free from my 160-170 hours on record, but occasionally you will witness things like falling through a floor during an attack or clipping into things that stay relatively solid. Nothing too bad, but it did hurt a little getting to the true final boss and falling through the floor RIGHT as I pulled out my nuke move.Upgrades- Remember how I said upgrades "should" be optional in places? This is where the game has the potential to be a real deal breaker for some. Most RPGs have proven that treasure chests are relatively optional unless something you NEED is in them. Ys: Origin loves planting things that make not getting OHKO'd/combat even remotely possible late game IN treasure chests and then giving you free reign to ignore them. This is not a complaint, but this HAS halted/slowed the progress of a few people Ive helped out on the forums. You should ALWAYS go for chests you see...even if it looks like a pain in the butt to get if you want to have a decent time above Easy mode.Overall, I give this an 8/10, its EASILY one of my favorite games (especially out of my Steam Library) but even I can see where this game would♥♥♥♥♥♥someone off.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												Ys origin is a great game,its an action-jrpg that has all the elements that makes Ys series great, the huge difficult bosses, the fast paced action, the amazing music. This one follows the style of the modern 3D Ys games like oath in felghana and ark of napishtim but the story is a prequel of the whole Ys series, before Ys I & II chronicles. It does a great job explaining how the story started with interesting characters and a plot that suits the game. Dont expect an amazing plot but its decent.As for the content, the game offers three playable characters (one fo them is unlocked after you complete the game with one of the first two) with different story for each one, also there is boss rush,time attack and an arena mode, so there is lots of things to do. Just for completion with one character you will need about 12 hours in normal difficulty.The game can be really hard so think carefully before starting it in hard mode for a first playthrough.I highly recommend this game for hack and slash action-jrpg fans.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												This game is what revived ARPGs for me. Fast paced combat, enough story to keep you mildly invested, and multiple characters to help fit more than one type of playstle. Ys Origin has many [noticible] flaws and successes, most of which make it the game it is today.Pros: 3 Playable characters- We have your battle axe wielding berserker-style teenager, your snooty mage, and your "Git gud and unlock me" Character. Each one plays differently because of movement, magic skills, or how well they can manage themselves in, what I like to call, "crisis" situations (instances where you end up in a terrible spot and thinking/reacting fast is your only means of survival".Jumping- FINALLY, A GAME WHERE I CAN PLAY AN RPG, FIGHT IN REAL TIME, AND JUMP!!!! Moving in 3 dimensions makes platforming puzzles and combat reach another level of challenging.Puzzles- Puzzles are NEVER stupidly difficult and one particular puzzle can actually be solved without getting a "mandatory" upgrade nearby as 2 of the 3 characters. Puzzles are more meant to keep you from "completely" blitzing through the game.Story- Story is spaced out enough that it will never wholely interrupt your climb through the tower, but will still be there to keep you interestedBoss Fights- Probably the crowning achievement of Ys games, the boss fights will almost ALWAYS let you have a ton of fun on any difficulty (Yes, even people like me who are frustrated on higher difficulties still enjoy Nightmare mode/Inferno mode for Oath in Felghana). The fact that most of them keep the same pace, or even speed up a bit near the end of the fight, keeps the adrenaline pumping and makes victories that much sweeter.Difficulty select- You can't change once you start...but at the beginning there are multiple difficulties for the casual/hardcore masochist in all of us. Very Easy mode for the people who just want to beat the game, all the way up to Nightmare for the people who want to be challenged/punished for slightly better unlockable rewards.Music- FOR THE LOVE OF EVERYTHING SACRED AND DEMONIC IN ALL WORLDS, THIS MUSIC IS AMAZING :L I am a SLAVE to the soundtracks in Ys games! Fanboying aside....we DO have many memorable tracks and a few that may put you to sleep (I'm looking at you 2nd sector >.<) but the tracks are all VERY good standalone....just not always for extended periods of time. The BGM will be the same for the ENTIRE time you are in a sector/until you enter a boss area, so get used to them.Cons- Combat playstyles- Each character can only really play one way...turning trash mob combat into tedium when you are a few levels shy of doing any real damage to enemies. Trash mobs WILL eventually turn into beat-em up sections if you need to go level grinding for any reason.Level to Damage scaling- You will get new armor and be able to upgrade your weapon as you play through the game but at the same time your level is just as dependant on your damage. If you are even 2 levels shy of where you "should be" you will do little to no damage. You will literally get a small damage/defense spike around certain levels just so you keep up, a pattern present in Ys: Oath in Felghana as well. The same applies to having a weapon too low level. I was at the 3rd boss of the game as the 1st playable character and I noticed I could barely do 2 damage to the guy. Turns out, I missed an upgrade partway through the tower section I was in; because the MOMENT I got it the boss was taking normalized damage again. Upgrade (as a result) are NOT optional, which may kill the game for you if you are playing on Hard/Nightmare and you are going in blind. Glitches- The game is relatively glitch-free from my 160-170 hours on record, but occasionally you will witness things like falling through a floor during an attack or clipping into things that stay relatively solid. Nothing too bad, but it did hurt a little getting to the true final boss and falling through the floor RIGHT as I pulled out my nuke move.Upgrades- Remember how I said upgrades "should" be optional in places? This is where the game has the potential to be a real deal breaker for some. Most RPGs have proven that treasure chests are relatively optional unless something you NEED is in them. Ys: Origin loves planting things that make not getting OHKO'd/combat even remotely possible late game IN treasure chests and then giving you free reign to ignore them. This is not a complaint, but this HAS halted/slowed the progress of a few people Ive helped out on the forums. You should ALWAYS go for chests you see...even if it looks like a pain in the butt to get if you want to have a decent time above Easy mode.Overall, I give this an 8/10, its EASILY one of my favorite games (especially out of my Steam Library) but even I can see where this game would♥♥♥♥♥♥someone off.

Posted: February 3, 2013
												If you're in to (japanese) Action-RPG's and like a great challenge when it comes to boss fights, I highly recommend Ys: Origin. There are 3 different playable characters with their own playstyles and multiple difficulties to choose from. The basic "grinding" and leveling system is fun and addictive. You'll just want to keep slaying enemies after another, before your accumulating +exp, +str and +mana regen meters run off. The levels have puzzles and ofc treasures aswell, so it's not all brainless grinding (though you still can't turn your brain off while leveling, it's easy to die to normal mobs unless you pay attention). The level designs are nice aswell, there's enough to explore and it's not linear at all.But the best part of Ys: Origin are the hard boss battles. (If you're experienced in this kind of genre, I recommend either Hard or Nightmare difficulty to make the best out of the fights) The boss tactics are quite varied, though many resembled me of Touhou games, just in 3D. In other words there's quite a lot of projectiles to avoid, and you can't take too many hits. The fights usually take some time to learn to execute good enough, but beating the boss in the end is a great feeling.The story isn't anything fancy unfortunately, so better not get your hopes up on that. Music on the otherhand is great, not the best of the best among the J-RPG composers, but still great. I love those upbeat tunes that play during the boss battles, they make the fights feel even more epic!The graphics are really outdated, since the orginal game was released in 2006. The characters are drawn as sprites, but the enviroment is in 3D and looked from an isometric perspective. Though, the game kind of has an old-school feel with it because of this, and it might not be a bad thing. But if you're bothered by the old look, this game is not propably for you.

												I strongly recommend playing this game. It is an action RPG where you can play through as three characters, the final character unlocking the true story behind the game. Posted: December 31, 2013
												I've not got incredibly far in this game but what I've played so far has been a blast. The controls (at least with an XBOX Controller) are tight and responsive, and the combat is very fun.However, the real treat in this game is the boss fights, which are hella cool and provide a pretty good challenge. I'd recommend a controller because the response time and precision of control you need is so exact. Some of the bosses go into bullet hell territory but many of them require precision jumps and dodges to beat. The common enemies don't really give you too much trouble, but there are areas where combinations of certain types of baddy provide a pretty satisfying clear up.The graphics are what you'd expect from a small budget Japanese game. They're functional, mostly sprite characters on poly backgrounds and the art style is nice enough if not a little generic. The particle effects are very nice and the fully 3D bosses look fantastic and really show the games artistic strength in full. But you're not really playing this game for the graphics.All in all I'd recommend it to anyone, especially at a sale price!

Posted: August 18, 2014
												Ys Origins is a mix between Diablo and Zelda, and it is very fun to play. Unfortunately the great gameplay, soundtrack and visuals are dragged down by downright cringeworthy dialogue and a by the numbers story with a very flat ending. The graphics are also a bit dated even for 2006 when this originally came out. However the game still has a charm of its own. The character sprites are well made and environments have clear and different themes and feels. The fast pace of the monster slaying is maybe a bit too often grinded into a halt when you have to sit through lengthy and uninteresting line exchanges between the monotone and cliche characters.One interesting thing of note is the other main character of the game, Hugo. He should probably get an award for the most edgy video game protagonist ever. Most of the cringe material of the game comes from his teenage rebel attitude. The story might have been much less cringy had I picked Yunica for playable character, but I also think the edginess is kinda charming and memorable.In conclusion the rock solid gameplay and soundtrack totally redeem this game from any negatives I might have towards it. It was a blast to play and a definite recommendation.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Now, let me just say that Falcom and Xseed games did a respectable job with this installment of the Ys series but it is not a game without its flaws. Lets start with the things I really liked. The gameplay was wonderful, honestly I would change a thing about it. Yunica moves where you want, attacks where you want, slaughters thousands of enemies in an effort to grind levels, the way you want... and umm hmm I'll talk about that pretty soon. The visual style was really good to look at with a SNES era feel to it. Although, same of the 3D environments looked a little choppy and jagged it was enough to take away from the game. I liked the good use of colour throughout the games many different environments. What I found really neat that despite the fact you spend the entire game inside a tower the developers still put floors dedicated to elements such as desert, water and lava. My favourite part of the game was hands down the combat which was a pleasure to utilize. The boss fights were always overwhelming and in general were very unique. They provided a great deal of challenge to the player and some would not be defeated easily. Just my basic two cents on what I feel was done right.On the other hand there are some areas for improvement that I feel should be touched on. Posted: December 31, 2013
												I've not got incredibly far in this game but what I've played so far has been a blast. The controls (at least with an XBOX Controller) are tight and responsive, and the combat is very fun.However, the real treat in this game is the boss fights, which are hella cool and provide a pretty good challenge. I'd recommend a controller because the response time and precision of control you need is so exact. Some of the bosses go into bullet hell territory but many of them require precision jumps and dodges to beat. The common enemies don't really give you too much trouble, but there are areas where combinations of certain types of baddy provide a pretty satisfying clear up.The graphics are what you'd expect from a small budget Japanese game. They're functional, mostly sprite characters on poly backgrounds and the art style is nice enough if not a little generic. The particle effects are very nice and the fully 3D bosses look fantastic and really show the games artistic strength in full. But you're not really playing this game for the graphics.All in all I'd recommend it to anyone, especially at a sale price!

The visual style was really good to look at with a SNES era feel to it. Although, same of the 3D environments looked a little choppy and jagged it was enough to take away from the game. I liked the good use of colour throughout the games many different environments. What I found really neat that despite the fact you spend the entire game inside a tower the developers still put floors dedicated to elements such as desert, water and lava. Posted: July 8, 2016
												A solid action RPG that properly balances the action and RPG elements, making for a fluid and fast-paced experience free of unnecessary frustration.The game essentially consists of multiple 'dungeons' strung together and with generous save points at various intervals, each of which you can travel between instantly using an inventory item.The dungeons are all consistent in layout in that they're conducive to the action RPG format; it's difficult to get lost and a path will usually branch two different ways at most, one leading to progress and one leading to a chest for example. This keeps the emphasis on the action as it allows you to storm through areas with very little fear of missing a key, new item or consumable.Combat is smooth and enjoyable, and the boss designs are excellent. Replay value is high given the various playable characters--each with their own play style--as well as multiple difficulty settings, bonus modes, unlockables and achievements.I didn't find the storyline very interesting, nor inspiring enough to make me want to explore the series further, though the dialogue is often funny. Which brings me to my main gripe being that the dialogue scenes can be long at times and are unskippable, bringing all the action to a halt intermittently. In addition, it can feel grindy at times in a somewhat imbalanced sense, in that you'll suddenly hit a wall in combat and have to trek back and grind for an hour or so before you can more easily proceed. Otherwise, entirely recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												Well, this be my first review... Dunno how to format it but i'll try my bestStory: The game has 2 normal endings but 1 true ending, giving 3 in total. While they of course vary, there are many things which stay the same in the story such as how each character progresses. At points this makes you believe you already know all the story and what's going on after one play through, but later on the story can completely take a twist for each character. Each story does start off pretty slow, especially if you go in without any prior knowledge to the Ys series, but once the plot thickens, it thickens good. It is pretty engaging and most the characters are quite understandable and likeable.Gameplay: I suggest you play the demo itself. On higher difficulties it can be fast paced, manic, epic and overall very enjoyable. There are a few moments in the game mind you where it can be frustrating trying to defeat a boss or enemy, because some of them are just soo cruel on the insane difficulty!.. Each character have 3 abilites they unlock through the game, each of them have their special uses for puzzle solving but also for combat, the main problem I find is that you unlock these all of these three abilites around half way, leaving not much else to unlock except for one super move or a sort per character (Which is awesome but missable) and passive abilities.One thing which did annoy me a lot though is how vague the game could be with it's in-game instructions. For example - if you play as Yunica the game will tell you about how you can use a descending jump attack, what it DOESN'T tell you until later, after soo many chances where it could have been useful, is that the attack is capable of stunning enemies, but since the attack does little damage alone you will probably spend a lot of time playing the game without knowing this gameplay element. Neither does the game explain thrusting or how the boost meter charges quicker when you have less health (Which is really essential to know for a certain task otherwise you could be waiting about for a good 30 minutes). Now, honest maybe it did explain some of these things in the game, but if it did, it obviously didn't make it's point since i'd completed the game twice without knowing some features...Visuals and Audio: Uh... Well this is a sorta old-ish game now, so the visuals aren't all that great for the 3D? models. Weirdly though I find the special effect in game to still look top notch, flashy and cool. The audio is fine really, I haven't much comments on it except that the OST is pretty epic and great, especially nearer to the end of the game.Overall: Since you can, I suggest you just play the demo first, it's a great game in pretty much everyway, there are a few moments which will make you pull out your hair but otherwise the experience as a whole is brilliant for the price.8/10

Posted: November 23, 2016
												Challenging, whimsical, emotional. Ys is an interesting series that I've stumbled upon a few years after its release. I was told that it was very "chatty" to which the common complaint was coupled with "should have had voice acting." I honestly went into this game only knowing that and nothing of the type of gameplay, combat, or the story elements I'd be facing. When I did, however, it was amazing. Ys Origin takes it's stand as a prequel to the following games before it: being Ys I, II, etc. I've never enjoyed such a vibrant set of characters before; each with their own unraveling stories AND abilities. Mastering the mechanics is some sort of joyous experience that only proves itself further when you go into boss fights. You'll be frustrated and tired of dying, but with those tight controls, well thought out music compositions, and charming graphics, you'll always come back for more.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Fun and positively addictive combat system. Grinding in this game is one of the best grinding experiences in ARPG. Boss battles are tricky and sometimes incredibly brutal, with an upward trend of difficulty in attack patterns and damage received from the first boss to the very last, which is always a crucial key in boss battles design.Storyline is straightforward and fluid with epic twists (the most literal sense of 'epic'). Covers most of the important key points that explain what happens in the main series, while also leaves very much room for personal interpretation and possibly retelling. Character designs are surprisingly intricate and interesting, considering the fact that Falcom had always been set with simplicity in all Ys titles until Ys Origin came out in 2006.Not much needs to be said about the music. Falcom JDK Band did a fantastic job as usual. I believe the music in Ys Origin is about as well-praised as that of Oath in Felghana. Beyond the Beginning is personally my favorite track.The only potential problem with the game is everything stays the very same throughout all three arcs, except for character combat mechanics, storyline, and minor spoiler: a true final boss. This can be boring to some people, but not to me personally.Overall, this is definitely a very solid and highly polished dungeon-crawler ARPG from Falcom, and a worthy title to mark the big jump of the series to Ys Seven. Absolutely a huge Yes from me.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												Ys Origin is an excellent game. I was expecting an average action rpg but it ended up being one of my favorite action rpgs to date. The game can be quite difficult at certain points, especially boss battles, even on the easier difficulties. Also the entire soundtrack is superb. So far I've finished the game with Yunica and I've started playing the game as the other two characters (the second of those two must be unlocked by beating the game with either Yunica or Hugo). Each character plays differently from the others and the story for each character is also different (although your going to be running through the same areas and fight most of the same bosses as well). After beating the game with a character it unlocks an arena mode for that character, other unlockables are also unlocked after beating the game with all three of the characters. I'd recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of action games or action rpgs, I'd say its a must buy.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												After playing Ys I and II, how I think of this game is much different. It drags along Ys I and II's coattails too much at times, so this hampers the story mode (recycled puzzles from those games, to name a few). Also there are a ton of unskippable cutscenes so it makes the multiple playthroughs required to get everything tiring.The gameplay is good aside from horrendous imbalance between characters (bosses were not balanced around multiple characters very well, so the worst character in the game will have loads of trouble against a boss that can easily be defeated with the "better" characters). Soundtrack is pretty great. 8/10Go play Oath in Felghana or Ark of Napishtim for a better Ys experience.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												-Wonderful Japanese Action Role-Playing Game. -The game is beautiful and the controls work wonderfully. Perhaps a controller would be easier to navigate but so far the keyboard hasn't been too frustrating. -The enemies all seem to be unique and pose different challenges.-The boss battles are so far very well crafted and takes some skill... again easier with a controller.-You unlock skills as you progress similar to how you would in say metroid... which I will mention because whenever you open a chest you get the wonderful metroid new upgrade sound effect.(That's what it sounds like to me!)-Music sounds great and well done.-Storyline so far is interesting and enjoyed the usage of the Sosarian Runes, which i know from the old Ultima games.. and is similar to Dwarven Runes from Lord of the Rings. All being based off of the Germanic languages. (So far not needed to know during the game, but provided some extra interest.)-Great save point locations so you don't waste too much time from deaths.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
												Ys Origin is an action RPG, with a hack and slash styled battle system. There are 3 playable characters, the 3rd being unlocked when you clear the game the first time with either of the first two characters. Each character has a very specific playstyle. Gameplay consists of your typical RPG fare: battling monsters while exploring your surroundings. In Ys Origin, you are tasked with exploring a giant tower that extends to the heavens. The tower is broken up into segments, with each segment offering a different environment to do battle in and explore. They are varied enough to where sometimes you forget you are in a tower and are instead traversing a dungeon located elsewhere. At the end of each segment (and sometimes in the middle) you are presented with a boss. The end of each segment is always a screen-filling boss, and these are the most fun parts of the game, each requiring some strategy to defeat.

The bosses are unforgiving, expecially if you pick the melee character to start with. And I like Dark Souls, I just hate the awful port that is on Steam. Go play it on a Playstation.

content:
Posted: January 2
												"Let me tell you a story of the beginning.....Of Ys"Set 700 years before the events of Ys 1 and 2 we venture to the destroyed world of Ys by an unknown force of demons.Days pass as the remaining survivers atop a floting island that they sent to escape the scorge of demons on the earth known as "Solomun Shrine" the 2 Goddesses that watch over the people of Ys Reah and Feena have disappeard along with the source of magic in the world of Ys "The Black Pearl"A group is dispatched to search for the godesses on the earth but are soon separated by an unknown force that attacked them on the way down from a tower that showed up out of nowhere.Shortly after regrouping the search party begins to climb the mysterious tower in search of their godesses only to find much more afoot the tower that awaits them.Unlike most Ys games where you plays as the title character "Adol the red" Ys origin gives us 3 different characters all together to play as.Yunica Tova: A young girl and Dauther of the Captain in Gaurd command that protect the godesses, She wields a small battle axe and is a "less mobile" Adol if you are familier with the other games.Hugo Fact: A mage in search of his missing brother and seeks to achieve great power, He wields "The Eyes of Fact" making Hugo the first Mage character to be playable in an Ys game as unlike Adol or anyone else he uses projectiles to fight from long range.Toal Fact: Hugo's older brother and was once a commander of the Gaurd for protecting the goddesses, Now a half-demon Toal's Action's seem questionable at first as he as sided with the enemy to achieve great power as well...or does he? (Unlockable only after beating the game once as Yunica or Hugo, Note: His story is the actual cannon to the series)Ys origin uses the same Ys engine that began with Ys VI and later improved in "Oath in Felghana" and as its own game and prequel story it holds quite well. Areas are broken to floors as you are climbing up the tower but variety exists as each floor as its own theme (Water, Sand, Fire ect) and its not just going up stairs upwards as they spice of the areas giving you places to explore for goodies and what not. However despite the variety in areas unlike other games in the series Origin is very linear in where you can and can't go to with only a very small bits of Exploring later down the line. There's also not that many Intresting characters to meet as most of them are either from the search party or the Villains of the game limiting the feel of a living world like previous games.Despite those small down parts Ys origin is still fun and challenging game like all other Ys games in the series.One small problem that kind of annoyed me is the Checkpoint systume. unlike the two eariler Ys games using this engine (Ys 6 and Oath in Felghana) if you die in an area/room you will restart from the start of that room and you can go back to a previous area if you are low on HP however Ys origin doesn't do that and instend your only means of checkpoints our the Goddess Statues that let you save the game/buy upgrades.Which means if you died a along ways through an area without getting to the next Statue its all the way back to the previous one, And while you can Teleport back to one at any point to save any progress you made (I.E points or Key story items) you still have to go all the way back to the last point you got to which on later Difficulties can get on your nerves sometimes.But if you've played any Ys game before and tried to beat it on Nightmare mode you should be pretty used to the pain and suffering by now. :P

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Okay, let's just get the obvious out of the way right now: The intro to this game is LONG. LOOOOONG. Like, possibly the longest intro to an RPG I've ever played.HOWEVER, once you get past the intro, you're introduced to the meat of the gameplay, and holy hell is it satisfying! The combat in Ys: Origin is fast placed hack n slash that seems mindless at first, but if you just mindlessly spam attacks with no thought, you will die. A lot.In fact, even if you're careful, you will most likely die a lot, because this game is HARD. The normal enemies are usually no trouble, though there are indeed cases where they can chump you if you're not careful, but the real meat of the difficulty lies in the boss battles.If you're at all familiar with the Ys series, than you probably know that one of the series' most lauded aspects is the incredibly designed, incredibly difficult boss fights, and Origin is no exception. You will most likely die to a boss at least once before you learn how to deal with them. And each boss as their own styles, attacks, and strategies, so each boss feels fresh and exciting.Also, did I mention the music? Because HOLY HELL the music is amazing. Quite possibly one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard.All in all, if you're looking for an RPG with fast paced action, an interesting story, amazing bosses, amazing soundtrack, and a difficulty level that constantly keeps you on your toes, then Ys Origin is for you. In fact, give the whole Ys series a try. Its a great series, and Falcom and XSeed are great companies that deserve your support.

Posted: May 19, 2013
												Falcom decided to revisit the Darm Tower from the first Ys game (and you even visit it again in Ys IV: Dawn of Ys), so while it's a barebones concept on paper, they actually reinvented the mazelike floors of the Tower wonderfully. For the first time in the series, you can play with different characters (Adol is still in the game, don't worry) and the music proves once again how this series can brag with having one of the finest scores in video game history.Sadly, in order to understand the full story, you have to go through the game with all three characters, which doesn't sound bad at all, but you still go through the same places three times and that can get boring.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2013
												Action-packed, a fine story, lots of great boss battles (AMAZING boss battles!)… this is a hacky-slashy JRPG that has it all. The game might look kind of old, but it’s still pretty and plenty of fun. If you’ve played OiF, then the gameplay will feel quite familiar. There are three (one of them must be unlocked) main characters, each with their own style of fighting. The story takes place before the events of Ys I and II, which fans suggest you play before starting this one. Don’t let that stop you from picking this one up whenever you can though! Show your support! Falcom and XSEED are a match made in heaven. I really hope they continue to bring over games to this side of the pond for a long time to come. Overall, Ys Origin has to be one of the best games I’ve bought on Steam, and I’m really happy to have it in my library.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2013
												The Ys series is a long runnning action RPG series from way back in the 1980s. In 2006 a prequel to the first two games in the series was made called "Ys Origin" it  allowed you to play as three different characters with three different playstyles and abilities. You got to move around a strategize how you were going to attack your foes with melee or magic spells in nicely done varied areas such as a water and fire sections. The game has some platforming and slight puzzle sections at times too which is a nice change of pace. Falcom here again did a nice OST to listen too while your killing those bosses or even when jumping from area to area or running down hallways killing everything in sight. The story as already mentioned is a prequel telling more of the story established in earlier Ys games and connecting them. It's nice and each character you play as has their own little portion in the plot I really like games that do that. If you are craving some action based JRPGs check out this game for sure you won't regret it! :)

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												An expansion pack sequel to Oath in Felghana, Ys Origin has much of the same feel of it's predecessor. New enemies and world to explore, but you handle exactly like Adol Christin, wind-powered spinny attack and all. Origin has three campaigns to justify that extra five dollars on the price tag, but they're all the same, with the exception of bosses. With the same puzzles and monsters, I finished Yunica's campaign but only scratched the surface of the other two, dropping them once I felt like I was going through the motions.What bothers me about the Ys series is that I don't think Falcom understand why their game is good. Every single one of their games starts with at least five minutes of cutscenes, with Oath in Felghana clocking in at 15 before you start to slay monsters. Game, I don't need you to tell me to beat up monsters. Legend of Zelda had an old man in a cave saying "take this sword and♥♥♥♥♥♥off" and I still saved the world without knowing why or caring. Damningly, around halfway through Yunica's campaign, you get thrown into a supposed-to-lose boss battle, and then your character mopes around for another five minutes of cutscene until your male love interest (no homo) cheers you up and encourages you to keep going. All the while I'm thinking about how much fun I'd be having if I was playing the game. This game needs less talky talky, more stabby stabby.Four out of five Lennys( ͡͡ ° ͜ʖ ͡ °) ( ͡͡ ° ͜ʖ ͡ °) ( ͡͡ ° ͜ʖ ͡ °) ( ͡͡ ° ͜ʖ ͡ °) ( )

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												This game serves as my introduction to the world of Y's (pronounced EES). I've been wanting to play a game in this series for a while and I'm so happy I picked this one up. A Diablo-style action RPG, this game is hella fun. I'm several hours into my first playthrough and have really enjoyed it so far. Challenging boss fights, decent level design that rewards you for exploring while providing a decent story. It's all a very solid and polished experience that's worth your time. A lot of games like this have mecahnics that suffer or that are a bit loose. To me, this is a crucial part of enjoying a game's platforming sections. It's very frustrating when you feel like you told your character to jump from the platform they're on to the one on the right only to find that you were pressing every so slightly in an upwards/downwards direction which caused you to miss the platform and fall into the pit. Not so here. I felt like I had good control over the character and rarely if ever made such a mistake that felt all too common even in AAA titles that are top ranked in their class. Overall I really can't find much to fault in this game. To nitpick I'd say the costumes are a bit plain when you're talking to others but this is also refreshing at the same time. It's simple, and practical. I would also say there maybe could have been more variety with the monsters but this doesn't really bother me at all either. It's just a fun game that's knows what it is and has fun being just that. If you like games like this I highly recommend giving it a try.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2012
												An incredible action RPG with 3 campains and a hard-rock soundtrack.  Each character has their own story that unfolds at a very pleasing rate, but these characters also go to the same places and almost do the same things.  As far as Ys games go this one is definitely one of the best.  One warning though, it is not the best Ys game to start on if you care about the story.  Gamplay wise this game is less like Ys Seven and more like Ys: The Oath in Felghana (Also on steam).  You have three crystals that you will obtain over time and you can upgrade them to do more stuff and get stronger.  This game also has an upgrade system for your armor, weapons, and resistances.  Music wise the Ys games are second to none, a blaring hard rock soundtrack (Plus remixes from Ys 1 & 2).  On a final note, if you like action RPGs or fantasy games this game here is a must buy.
