number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
												The Ys series is one of the longest running franchises around. As far as RPGs go, there isn't really another series to compare with this. Ys Book I & II was one of (if not the 1st) action RPGs. And even today, there aren't many other games that do it better. Even though Ys Origin was released many years after I & II, Origin stays true to what make an Ys game, an Ys game. You can always expect brutal boss battles, a compelling story, an absolutely amazing soundtack, enjoyable characters, beautiful visuals, & unforgiving gameplay.I fell in love with this series back in the late 80's on my TGCD. I just about crapped my pants when I heard Ark of Napishtim was being released on PS2 & made it an immediate purchase. Now years later finding a treasure trove of Ys games on Steam... how am I supposed to resist?The Ys series may not get the recognition of the Final Fantasy or Dragon Quest franchises(at least not in the US), but it ought to. Being the 1st game in the Ys series(timeline wise), Origin is a great way to be introduced to one of the best RPGs around. I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												It's a satisfying hack and slash game, but keep in mind, this is not a title for the intellectual gamer. I'll start by explaining what I don't like before what I do like. (IMPORTANT - This game is not worth $19.99. Get it when it goes on sale.)The writing is horrible and the game treats you like a baby that can't figure anything out on your own. For example, I entered a zone on the 12th floor that would quickly drain my HP simply by being there, forcing me to leave the area. When the character said that it felt like an evil sound boring into her head, I checked my inventory and saw the silver harmonica given to me by one of the goddesses. I figured "No brainer right? I just got this thing, so obviously this is the solution." I go back into the zone and try using the harmonica, but it doesn't work. And not in the context that the character tried using it, but failed. I mean I went to use the item and got the equivalent of Prof. Oak saying "Now is not the time to use that." No, you have to call somebody outside of the room, listen to a conversation, and have the character say bluntly that "Hey, look at this here harmonica. I'll betcha that will solve the problem." So now, I don't feel like somebody who used reasoning to deduce the solution to a problem. I feel like my hand is being held. (And yes, I know that the harmonica still doesn't technically work even after the conversation, but it still serves the purpose of progressing the game.)And again, the writing is fanfiction levels of god awful. Maybe if the writing were better and didn't look like it was tailored to pre-teens, the story could possibly be decent. But with writing like this, there's no way any adult could enjoy it. ---As for the good things about the game, despite not being the deepest combat system, it's very fast paced and feels extremely satisfying. I've played the game for about 6 hours now and I'm still not tired of the button mashy combat. Enemies spit out tons of resources after being defeated, giving that packrat portion of our minds a constant tickle. My favorite part of the game would have to be the boss fights. Unlike other aspects that treat you like a child, these boss fights are pretty brutal. I'm playing the game on hard mode, and I've had to go through these fights at least 10 or so times before coming away victorious. I love that there's actually room to strategize in these fights. Like a giant centipede that drops poison time bombs from its destroyed body parts. Do you try your best to methodically clear out the bombs, or do you continue assaulting the boss and hope to outlast them? And while you do have the opportunity to go back and grind out some levels to make it easier, these bosses will still command all of your attention.  Overall, I don't believe the game is worth the asking price of $19.99. If the writing were better and if the zones actually had secrets and left more room for exploration, then it would be a no brainer. As it stands, Ys Origin is a fairly straightforward hack and slash that is very good when you're actually playing the game, but suffers when anybody opens their mouth. Again, get it on sale for sure. Around $4.99 is more than acceptable.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Ys Origin plays like a top-down hack-and-slash but can at times be so frantic it feels like a bullet hell. Think Zelda on steroids. An interesting story, awesome gameplay, and very challenging. Well worth the money and made me purchase the other Ys games - which I am also enjoying.You are given the choice of playing as a girl with a big axe or a guy with magic. After you beat the game you can go ahead and replay it with the other character or with a new, 3rd character. Playing it with the girl or guy you're first given feels generally the same, although you obviously have an entirely different set of skills. All three characters pretty much trek through the exact same dungeon layout but the 3rd character you unlock fights a set of new bosses and has an entirely different story. Playing on higher difficulties actually changes things besides HP and damage - although the story stays the same.One downside is that I feel that the leveling was pretty tedius. You will find yourself in positions where you need to grind out 5 levels because it is literally impossible to beat a boss if you don't have the damage output. This only takes maybe 10-15 minutes before each boss but later in the game I remember having to spend an entire hour just beating up 1,000 grunts.Defintely one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a while.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												Ys Origin is one of the best games I've ever played.It has the perfect balance between story, music and gameplay.  The combat is simple to learn but hard to master if you want to tackle higher difficulties or venture into Arena or Time Attack mode.  You'll probably want to use a controller.  The story in this game is simply one of the most perfectly paced and emotionally driven games I've had the pleasure of playing.  This game completely blows every other Ys game out of the water (Take that, Adol!).  If you're a Ys fan, or any sort of JRPG fan, or even an anime fan, this game was made for you.With every track of music that is perfectly tuned for each area to match the locale, to the incredibly deep characters that have their own personal motivations and feelings, this game will blow your socks off and keep you guessing about some of the characters until the very end.  This is what game design should be about.  Graphics don't matter, they don't have to cost millions of dollars, they just need a little bit of love.Praise the Goddesses.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												It's a very linear game and the plot is pretty unoriginal, but executed well enough to make me feel emotionally invested in the later boss battles.  Each level is a 3D puzzle platformer full of hacking and slashing.  Many of the later boss battles become like shoot-em-up/bullet hell games, except that you A: fight melee (if you choose the melee character, which I did), and B: can jump over the bullets.  Each boss requires a nuanced combination of strategies.The RPG elements are pretty minimal, and the XP system is such that you can't grind ahead of the area's level, but you always catch up the area's level before you reach the boss, even if you try to avoid enemies.  IMO that's a pretty good thing, since it means that there is nothing to distract you from the meat of the gameplay.  (It is vital that you find all of the hidden items, though, at least on hard mode).Also, while the environments are kinda simple, some of the shader effects look pretty good, the character portrait and sprite art are beautiful, and special effects for character and boss attacks are completely ridiculous (but totally interactive and quite sophisticated; pretty much no scripted execution nonsense).Oh, and I forgot to mention that the music is fantastic.  I still regularly listen to the soundtrack.

												This one is for those thirsty for quality JRPG action! A very well designed game both in graphics and sound. Not the most thrilling of plots but very well written, nevertheless. 												I did not expect the game to be as good as it is, sure, the intro sequence is a bit long in the absolute beginning of the game, but after that you have very little that is dragged out at all in the game, story is decent with good characters(At least the one I've played) and combat is pretty fun.Also, something that is a selling point for me personally, it isn't as heavy on the stats-department as other RPGs, IE you do not need to level up individual stats or numbercrunch with a calculator, you just get better stuff, that's it. Also lastly, experience gain scales with how high level you are, so catching up to an area in levels isn't too hard, usually requires just going in and out of a room and mopping up the enemies while having the double EXP bonus going.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Ys Origin is a good game. It's worth every bit of money I spent on it. But it's not perfect. There are some flaws with the game that prevents the game from being great.1) The story-If you've already played Ys back in the golden age of the Super Famicom, you'll probably appreciate the story in this prequel. But if you never played them, chances are you'll be disappointed with the story. It's very cliche and predictable. Even worse is the story for each characters. Long story short, each of them aren't parallel with each other.2) The difficulty-Hard games are good and welcomed but the difficulty in Ys Origin is borderline cheap and unfair. Basically, the higher difficulty means enemies have more health, takes less damage and deals more damage to you. It pretty much boils down to grinding enough levels by killing the same enemies over and over again, just to inflict damage more than 1 to the enemy. That, and finding power-up item to strengthen your weapon because if not, the later stages becomes nearly impossible. Unless you're a masochist or have a lot of free time, just play it on normal or easy.3) The gameplay-It's fun enough for a few hours, especially after getting all abilities but it get pretty old as you play. Equipment, stats, abilities, items, etc are all streamlined and simplified. You'll be begging for more complexity the more you play. Almost no exploration or secret locations to discover, a few unneeded platforming and a non-existent puzzles to solve.  I'm giving this a thumbs up simply because it succeeded in giving me a brief moment of enjoyment.RECOMMENDED        : For Ys fans. If not, buy this during a sale.NOT RECOMMENDED: Player who seeks more complexity than slash-fest J Action RPG

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Decent game, not a very worthy addition to the Ys Series as a whole though... The back story on Ys was something I never cared about and this game didn't really do a good attempt at making me care now... so yeeeeeah. I'd reccommend it to both casual and masochistic gamers just for the solid gameplay alone.The difficulty is quite insane and requires hours of training if you intend to complete it on Nightmare mode. Unfortunately completing the game on the hardest setting is the only way to get the full experience and unlock all the extra goodies like alternate costumes / characters and most of the achievements.It's quite tedious if you intend to experience the entire story as there are three playable characters and the final and true story arc doesn't unlock until you complete the game with the first two characters... not to mention if you're one of those loliconners you unlock a school girl outfit for the main by completing the game an additional THREE times after the initial three playthroughs... it's kind of unreal... I mean just go download some porn, it's faster and healthier.I'd stick to easy mode and experience the paltry story just to say you've "Been there and done that" if you're a casual Ys fan... Easy = Fun, Nightmare = NONE. Keep that credo in mind if you decide to purchase it.

												Many have dismissed Ys Origin as a cheap cash in game, a place holder between other, more successful games. Yet I'm not one of those; sure, it's basically Ys I&II: The Before Years, but that's EXACTLY why I enjoy the game. Ys as a series has been sorely lacking in back story; many key events in the past have been teased by Falcom, yet we've never seen them. Ys Origin, thankfully, does the job of offering us SOME insight to the history of the flying island, several bosses/main villains of Ys I&II and, finally, the reason why the Goddesses of Ys lost their wings.Even though Oath of Felghana and even Ark of Napishtim are better in certain aspects, Origin IS NOT in any way truly inferior to them. It has the same great engine and game play of the others, and despite, or perhaps maybe in spite of the fact that it's all contained within Darm Tower, Ys Origin earns its place in my heart for giving me precious back story that's been so scarce.Oh, and Adol is unlockable. JOY!

content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												This is a game I really want to like, but it's just too flawed. The bosses I played were very creative and possibly some of the best I've seen in a game of this genre. So why don't I recommend it? First off, unskippable, long, unnecessary intro. Supposedly you can skip it if you've beaten the game - still not acceptable. The next major beef is the bizarre leveling system. One character level can mean the difference between unbeatable boss and wow, that boss was easy peasy. Finally, the boss and area that made me pretty much quit early was the Construct. Cool boss design, but I'd like to damage him successfully. The fight is pretty much you play for like 2-3 minutes to be able to take off a tenth of his health bar. It's an easy fight, but the patterns are so predictable that it just feels like a massive waste of time. The next area, I don't know what happened. Maybe I shouldn't have been able to beat that boss, but the standard enemies just became massive damage sponges. Went from dealing like 40-60 damage per hit to 2-7. Just completely unfun. It could have been a great game, but balance issues run amok it seems.

number of helpful: 51 of 119 people (43%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												Ys isn't as bad as the first few hours make it seem.  There's enough about it that's bad enough to give it a thumbs down, but it's definitely done some things pretty well.  This review lists major points concisely with more detailed explanations at the bottom.Here are the flaws I've seen so far:-Character and item upgrade systems are pathetically bad.-Uninspired levels.-The 'puzzles' involve finding an item and backtracking to use it.  -Framerate issues with some graphical effects.-Controls need autofire and autocharge.  Other control problems may be specific to me.-Too many rpg text dialogs that can't be skipped.  -The difficulty curve isn't right.  -The rate of levelling needs adjusting, and the effect of gaining levels is not done well.  It increases damage done and decreases damage taken, altering boss fight difficulty too much.Game's strong points:+The bosses are very challenging with fully-avoidable attacks+The action is fast-paced.  +The graphics are colorful, and I like the graphical style of the characters.Regarding difficulty,On Hard difficulty with the magic user, the monsters are a joke, unable to threaten the player.  The bosses are very challenging.  On nightmare difficulty with the melee character, the (skippable) trash monsters are about right, but the bosses are extremely challenging.  There is at least 1 boss fight that cannot be won without grinding due to its being a dps race.  It is not obvious that grinding is the intended (and only) way to win the encounter.  Grinding 5 levels for that fight also reduced the boss's attacks from 40 dmg/hit to 9 dmg/hit.  I do not know how hard those bosses are supposed to hit, and I suspect the developers don't either.  Without grinding, nightmare bosses can take 1-10 hours to beat, including the time to learn their moves.Unskippable dialogsare ubiquitous and boring.  Even if I were interested in reading the story of a hero who rescues princesses and saves the world, my replays through the game would not be.The intro cinematic is well done, but it can't be skipped either.  It takes at least 15 minutes to start a new game due to the unskippable cut scenes and dialog.The controlsdesperately need an autofire button and a way to hold down the magic charge button.  Using outside configuration utilities creates some problems in the game such as menus opening and closing due to autofire.  Holding down the magic charge button while imtermittently holding down the attack button and periodically jumping has led to some hand soreness.  Without autofire, the repetitive button presses will cause a lot of repetitive stress.Even after some configuration, there are still occaisional phantom axis motions, and recharging magic immediately after casting makes it cast twice.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												I will be reviewing this game in stages as I play it.My expectations are, from reading reviews, a game with a good story.So I chose my character, and pressed start. Actually getting to gameplay took almost 11 minutes of unskippable-cutscenes and dialouge (with me jamming through skippable dialouge). One of my biggest criteria for a game is how long it takes me to be able to PLAY the game. This can be mitigated by interesting presentation. Ys Origin does not have interesting presentation.7 minutes til you can start pressing a button. 7 minutes to get past "So there was a paradise named Ys. Then demons showed up. Twin goddesses lifted their city into the sky. Demons made a tower to get at them. Then the goddesses left. You're a member of the team to track them down in the tower." Then you spend 4 more minutes scrolling through "Where am I? I better go to the tower". Finally, after ANOTHER cutscene showcasing the Barad-Dur rip-off, you get to the tower and start fighting the monsters. But this is broken up by lots of clumsy tutorializing. Skip ahead a few more minutes and you get actual control. So if you want to start a new game, expect close to 20 minutes before you get to play the game. Great. Excellent pacing. I'm sure there's other games out there that aren't there to pad their length out artificially.So far other reviewers have let me down. This isn't an interesting story, this is a PREMISE. The characters are anime archetypes. One is an apprentice fighter girl (despite the long♥♥♥♥♥intro saying they're sending their ELITES) and an brusque, impatient mage. The gameplay feels like a solid PS1 era dungeon crawler. Feels a bit primitive but functional. The pacing is utterly awful. If you have lots of time on your hands, you might like this.More to come as I play a little more.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												I am really amused how much good reviews this game got on steam. Most likely game is overrated because of nostalgia.pros:- Great platformer- Story- Soundtrack (for those who like such music)cons: - not an RPG at all (by modern standarts)- unskippable video: long and predictable hence boring- uninspired level design, too repetitive- Spam attack button to win on hard difficulty.- Spam attack button to win on nightmare difficulty.*** for those who are going to argue about difficulty, yes, bosses may be tough, everything else - just spam attack button.gameply:1. Watch unskippable anime (or just minimize the game and do something fun)2. Spam action button to skip tons of text (or read it if you haven't played any RPG video games in your life)3. move your character for a few seconds4. spam action button to skip text (or read it)5. spam action button to defeat your enemies6. spam action button to skip text7. move your character and spam attack (which is the same as "action") button8. repeatconclusion:It is very easy to like this game: Solution #1you need a few things:- love anime in general- remember original game - have nostalgiaSolution #2You haven't played any RPG games before, or played only jRPG games.Solution #3You just like easy-going pace of this ... well ... combination of non-interactive story and attack button simulator.

Posted: June 14, 2014
												Ys Origin (and the Ys series for that matter) is an odd combination of RPG/Platform/Puzzler but that doesn't stop it from being a surprisingly enjoyable game.The RPG elements are light, with upgradable equipment, attack choices and bonuses to pick up from defeated monsters in a arcade style way of handling temporary buffs. Story-line wise, there's nothing ground breaking here with some 'world is ending, must save it' fayre but the dialogue between characters is strong and there's just enough intrigue implied throughout to make you want know what's going to happen next.On the downside, some may find the combat element repetitive but it is fast paced and the dearth of creatures with their different attack patterns should keep things interesting. Boss battles on the other hand are a different kettle of fish, bold and brash with more than a nod to old school 90's boss fights they are tricky and engaging, providing you with a real sense of achievement when you finally succeed in downing the overseer blocking your path.Graphically it's not going to win any awards, lets be honest, it's functional but plenty of set pieces (normally coupled in with the boss fights mentioned above) provide the highlights in what is an average looking game. However the art style has it's own unique character which has been maintained since the original release of Ys, which is charming and beautiful all the way through.This is a solid game, plenty to keep you occupied and with a meaty enough story for each of the playable characters to deserve a playthrough, which is all well and good as if you're out hunting achievements, multiple playthroughs await you. Give it a look, especially if it's on sale, you'll be glad you did.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												So I know I haven't gotten very far into this, but I will say this: If you are a fan of old school hack and slash games like Illusion of Gaia, or Terraigma or even the other games in the Y's series I'd say pick this up. It's simple, fluid controls make combat a breeze, the light RPG elements and combos are fun and the story it self actually holds up pretty well and surprised me at the production values and what I saw! I mean this is not multi-million dollar production, but it does have cut scenes, like-able characters and even some psuedo anime/cg thrown in for good measures. It reminds me of those games of yesterday and I have to say I enjoy it's simplicity and fun combat. A good pick up and play for an hour or two at a time.

Posted: July 26, 2013
												Ys Origin is a fast-paced hack and slash rpg, there is no staying behind and preparing your mana... Thats probably the same as giving away openings to your enemies in this game.I love these kinds of games, and cannot wait for them to release it for the PS Vita! Ys Oath in Felghana runs on the same engine it appears, but if you want another Ys game but a little bit different, pick up Ys Seven, it's awesome.Played this game for 40 minutes, and im already lovin' it! Haven't faced a boss yet, but im guessing it's very much like Oath in Felghana; learn the moves and dogde them, look for openings, and try not to take any damage (make sure you are at the appropriate level for the boss fight!).Don't worry about being bored grinding up levels, it's not all that boring, it's quite addictive if you enjoy this kind of gameplay. the more hits, the bigger the combo, the more XP you earn, and this is very fast-paced!There's loot to pick up, items and armor to find, checkpoints to activate, and magical objects to obtain that gives you special skills! I've played through Ys Seven on my PS Vita, and it took more than 20 hours to complete!Ys Origin is an addictive and fun game that you should check out on youtube. If it strikes your fancy, i recommend you pick it up!

Posted: December 29, 2013
												"Ys Origin is a Japanese action role-playing game developed and published by Nihon Falcom for Microsoft Windows in 2006." (Wikipedia, November 2013)I've played this RPG for 45 hours on the hardest of the 5 difficulties (nightmare, hard, normal, easy, very easy) with "Hugo" (1 of 3 characters) and completed it by level 52. I found the story to be a run-of-the-mill "good guy wants power, turns evil temporarily, and repents through the power of friendship/love". I'm generally not the type of guy to delve into, and enjoy, the story of a game very much anyways, so I didn't mind it. In fact, considering that I look for "great gameplay" in games, and what type of gameplay I'll tend to go for, I would practically expect a story to be "the usual" in a game (not to say I haven't enjoyed original stories). I don't know how the story goes with the other 2 characters, since I haven't played them yet.This game, played with a top-down camera angle, plays kinda like a shooter when Hugo is the chosen character, as his attacks revolve around shooting magic missiles straight ahead of him. After a quick test run, the other 2 characters appear to revolve around close-range melee combat. On the hardest difficulty level, the bosses offer such a challenge that you'll find yourself grinding a lot, just to gain that extra level or two and be able to defeat the boss at all (and even then, your battle strategy better be near perfect). This game has some simple puzzle-solving, if you can even call it that. You'll find yourself having to press buttons, defeat certain enemies, obtain and use items/skills, and so on. I did enjoy the challenging gameplay, but it would get frustrating at times with bosses, and also 1 time with a certain enemy that can practically insta-kill you (but that you'll still have to deal with). The only thing to do there is keep looking around for equipment and the like, and grind in special spots to gain levels.If you want to know how nice the graphics look, just "You-Google-Tube" some gameplay footage on the game. And while you're at it, check out the soundtrack for it as well. It's pretty awesome. As of this post, the game is normally $19.99 USD on Steam and I'd say it's worth the price if you love to spend many hours on a challenging "battle-grind" RPG. If it turns-out that you love the game, then you may also love "Ys: The Oath in Felghana", which follows a similar gaming style. You may want to avoid Ys I & II though, which has your main attack revolve around ramming into enemies (like in Hydlide), which ruins any sense of "gameplay" (at least in my opinion).

Posted: December 27, 2013
												Even though Ys Origin is now a relatively old game (it was first released by the end of 2006), it still has plenty to offer to RPG fans:   - Beautiful graphics, both in-game and cutscenes   - Simple and intuitive graphic user interface   - Very fun, rewarding, fast-paced action that hardly gets old   - Challenging bosses that will make you rethink your playing strategy   - Not one, nor two... but three different game stories that seemly complement each otherDefinitely a great introduction to the Ys series and great improvement from the previously released title, The Oath in Felghana, except maybe in the soundtrack which in my humble opinion lacked that trilling component that made me want to carry on shredding monsters just to keep hearing the track. However, this is more than compensated by the deeply intriguing game stories; more than once I found myself playing an extra hour just to find out what was going to happen next.Overall, even if you're one of those players that rush through games (which I highly discourage with this one), Ys Origin is guaranteed to give you a good 30+ hours of gameplay any noteworthy action RPG should.

Posted: May 25, 2014
												The Ys series is, from what I recall, one of the big names in the Action RPG circuit, and Ys Origin changes the original formula of the first game (Ys 1 and 2, technically the second being an extension of the first rather than a separate game) by making it more actiony than RPG-y if that makes even the slightest bit of sense (it doesn't).That being said, this is still a rather fun game to play. The story's nothing to cry home about, but it's engaging enough to make you want to learn more about characters. Basically an okay plot, points for that.Gameplay is fantastic; three unique characters that each get their own special abilities and varied fighting styles, as well as boss battles that are tailored to their story rather than set bosses (though set bosses still appear). Again, more actiony than RPG-y, but it makes it fun.The music helps carry the game, since it almost obviously coined the term "rpg combat music". It is literally as generic fantasy-rock as you can get. I swear this is how a music company got its start. The music still helps the game move along.Overall a rather fun game to play, and one of the few I've played multiple times just to see everything. The other Ys games are about as good, so if you have money to burn, this is worth it, but definitely get it on sale if you can.

Posted: February 15, 2014
												Fantasic game. It's an excellent prequel to Ys 1&2. It does a great job leading into the other games in the series if you've never played them, and ties up all the loose ends if you have played them. All difficulty levels pose some level of challenge, even on the easiest setting, which keeps with the Ys tradition of hair-pulling moments. This game really appeals to me as an avid Ys enthusiast because of all the refernces to Ys 1&2 that aren't story related. Obviously, as a prequel, many story elements have a lot to do with the events of other games, but it's the more subtle references that I enjoy. I especially liked the fact that most of the bosses are from the original games, but the fights are different. I get to see the familiar names and remember my experiences from the original games but have unique and refreshing fights with them. Also, the rendition of "Termination" in this game is completely kickass.

Posted: May 13, 2013
												It's a pretty decent hack'n'slash ARPG, if that's all you're looking for, but it doesn't particularly stand out unless you're there for the Ys part of it. The combat is solid but doesn't have a ton of depth. The characters are likable but don't have a ton of depth. The story is your standard "bad guys did something bad; now the good guys better do something about it" fare, so it won't carry anything on its own (not to mention it only shows up for a few minutes of exposition every hour or so). It would be a fairly satisfying little timekiller that doesn't really stand out in any way except for one thing: a lot of the unlocks feel like they're on a free-to-play schedule in a non-free-to-play game.The higher tier upgrades in the story mode take an absurd amount of grinding to pay for. Can't beat a boss? Grind some levels, because a single level's worth of stats will make an enormous difference in the damage you deal/take. Two levels will change a fight from brutally hard to a pushover (although that's more "return of the 90s" than "when free-to-play games attack"). There are a bunch of bonus game modes you can unlock and extra characters and alternate character versions with different attacks and all sorts of stuff like that, but they require beating the entire story mode so many times (and weirdly, most of the achievement requirements are also "beat the game multiple times") that I'm guessing at least 90% of people will never even see things like arena mode. I know I certainly won't, even though I'd try it out if it were available immediately after having beaten the game the first time. It makes Korean MMOs look like they're concerned that you don't get outside enough.Aside from that, it's fun enough, but I'd mostly only recommend it to people who want more backstory to the Ys games.

												The music is amazing worth buying for that alone. Challenging boss fights also make the game more interesting and fun.

Posted: July 12, 2015
												Ys Origin is a classic Japanese RPG, with old school graphics, but which have their charm; and musics are very cool. Kinematics are made with illustrations in a manga style, allowing to tell the general story of why we are there and why it is like that. As usual in every good Japanese RPG, we have a cool bad guy, with long and brilliant hair, which wants to control the world of Ys for a random reason, and which has some underlings in order to stand in your way.The game takes place completely in a tower, we climb gradually its levels, by exploring every floor, collecting what we find as equipment and killing everything we can, jumping from time to time on platforms to move forward. At the end of every level, we have a boss to explode. There are 6 levels, each one has around 3 floors, and every level has its universe (fire, water, sand…). Yes because there are completely aquatic floors. In a tower. And above, there is a lava world. And also a forest. Yes. In a tower. A TOWER. :DAs a consequence, we adapt our fighting techniques to every level. For example thunder is very effective on the aquatic monsters, whereas fire will be effective against plants. Hello, Pokemon players!There are several difficulties, it goes from Very Easy to Nightmare. YS Origin will take about ten hours to finish with a first character.About characters, we have the choice between a knight girl and a magician boy. The first is a specialist of hand to hand fights, with special techniques in short and medium-range, the other one is a specialist of remote fight. Besides the difference of gameplay, every character has its own nature and background. This will influence a bit the global scenario, but the final goal won’t change: prevent the bad guy with nice hair from destroying the world. In other words. So big potential of replaying, in spite of the repetitive aspect of the game, especially because a third character is unlocked in the end of the game, as well as the bonus games like Time Attack mode or Arena, to kill a lot of monsters in a limited time.Conclusion: a good RPG as Japaneses know how to make it, with a manga universe both in graphics and musics. The gameplay brings nothing innovative but is very pleasant. Can be rather repetitive in the long run.

Now yes I recommended that you try Oath of Felgana just to test the waters but this game is for those who want to know the backstory behind it all. Posted: February 15, 2016
												This is definitely a Classic style Action JRPG. The boss battles are downright cruel and the environment is challenging enough to annoy you, but the smooth, responsive and easy to setup controls, compensated for the difficulties. The backstories are interesting. When you finish the game for the first time, it will unlock the third character, do another playthrough with this character to reveal the whole storyline, it's worth it.

Posted: March 14, 2016
												The more I immerse myself in the Ys series, the more enamored I become.  This is one solid little franchise.  There are so many things that Falcom does right in caring for this classic property, and I have high hopes for future Ys games I will be playing.  This is yet another perfect little charming gem of an action RPG.  It mixes 2D sprite animation and seamless 3D architecture to create a style both retro and timeless.  The care and attention payed to the characters, story, music, and ys heritage is truly admirable.Design wise, this game is a typical dungeon crawl, but the challenge is quite thrilling during boss fights.  The exploration aspect can get a bit tedious if you play through the game multiple times in quick succession, but I imagine this can be offset by tweaking difficulty levels to your liking. On that note, the story of Ys Origin plays out with a Roshamon style redundancy; with three individual character's story-lines.  Much of the joy of this game comes from experiencing the events of the narrative from these different perspectives.  Granted, there are slight differences in each Character's narrative, with only one (Claw's) considered 'cannon', but walking through the game in each of their shoes lets you become much more familiar with the characters and the world in which they live.  I can't imagine having only played through this game with a single character, and I found each separate run interesting and challenging due to the different play mechanics.  It's a faithful loveletter to the Lore Falcom has developed for Ys over the last several decades.  The characters, the settings, and even the music is heavily inspired by past games in the franchise.  Now at the time of this writing, I had managed to play the steam releases of Ys 1&2, as well as Oath in Felghana (remake of ys 3).  These games stand perfectly fine on their own story wise, and it is absolutely unnecessary for anyone to have any prior knowledge of the franchise to get your money's worth.  That being said, each entry also helps to paint a beautifully detailed picture of a larger whole.  Falcom seem quite devoted to the world they've created, and the relationship between games is actually quite nuanced.  I'm so very glad I played through this, and I encourage everyone to take it for a spin.  If you're only interested in a charming hack 'n slash romp, by all means coast through it.  If you're at all interested in the story of Ys, I very much encourage you to experience each story line.  On the lower difficulties, each play through should take about 8 hours.  I, myself, played the first round on normal, then coasted through the next two on easier settings for a total playtime of 26 hours.

Posted: June 19, 2015
												I'm doing an Ys marathon, except for Celceta which I have yet to get and 7 which I'm still playing, this is my favorite gameplay wise. The story's ok and explains Ys' history well before the events of 1 and 2. While Yunica's story is ok and Hugo's was intruiging, The Claw's ending is the only one that's canon. Gameplay wise you get 3 different playstyles. *Yunica uses an axe and later a sword as her main weapons, she can be a bit challenging since she's not the fastest character around but she's also a bit of a tank so you can muscle your way out of enemies with little damage. *Hugo's my favorite and the game just turns into a semi-bullet hell shooter. He shoots pretty fast and you will get upgrades along the way that will increase your projectiles for a duration. He's a mage so the typical low health, crazy magic damage applies to him . His shooting range is enough to be able to shoot enemies from afar.*The Claw plays as a hack and slasher. He's a good balance of health and strength and he has a nifty transformation that's fun. do a boost attack then talk to the RoosAfter you're done with the story, you also get Boss Rush mode and a bonus shop to use for a new game. There's nothing new in the story after but if you're a completionist and/or would like to clear all difficulty, you'll find much replayability in this game. I'm currently easing myself starting from very easy until I can tackle Nightmare without ragequitting.

Posted: December 24, 2014
												I didn't know what to expect when I bought this game, but I've enjoyed it immensely.  The gameplay is somewhat reminiscent of the older Zelda games, and it's very, very fast-paced.  The graphics are definitely showing their age (the game was originally published in Japan in 2006 or so), but don't really detract from an otherwise enjoyable experience.This has been one of my favorite recent purchases.  I hope XSEED is able to publish English translations of more stuff like this and Oath in Felghana (which is also fun, but not quite as good).Pros:-Fast paced, fun gameplay-Interesting bosses-Can reduce the difficulty of boss encounters by grinding a bit to raise character level (good if you're as bad at the boss fights as I am)-Although grinding is necessary, there's an XP multiplier based on the number of hits you've made in the last few seconds, so it's possible to grind more quickly by fighting only in crowded rooms-Responsive controls-Good soundtrack-Pretty good replay value--although the levels are all the same, each of the three playable characters has their own story arc with slight variations in the boss sequence and various other details-Very good localization work by XSEED; doesn't feel rushed at all-Runs very smoothly on modern hardwareCons:-Graphics a bit stale-Long cutscenes and dialog that cannot be skipped (note: there IS an option in the settings applet which suppresses ALL video playback; good for skipping the intro on a second play-through)-Character level scaling is very drastic:  Gaining two levels is usually sufficient to turn an unwinnable encounter into a cakewalk, so this tends to inspire a decent amount of grinding-You NEED to find all items, particularly weapon power-ups; there are some enemies that are virtually impervious to damage if your weapon is at too low a level.

Posted: August 12, 2012
												Previously cleared this prequel of YS  when the original Japanese version was released for PC, but purchased and cleared again for nostalgia when it was re-released on Steam. Gameplay (as stated in another review of YS) is action-RPG'ish (resembling both Zelda and Diablo), as the player controls the main character from an overhead third person view. Characters can be unlocked within the game, offering up to 4 (one is unofficially unlocked) different selections each with their own types of skill sets. Characters can level up and acquire a set of sword-skills and magic to demolish enemies that are encountered throughout the game. Storyline is paced well, but can be tedious to understand, as the lore of YS is quite deep in this version of the game. Must play as all three storyline characters to completely understand each of their motives. Music is also amazing, setting the tone of each and every stage the character enters. Graphics are outdated by modern standards, but the gameplay and music completely allow the user to forget about it. Played through the entire game with all three characters (Yunica/Hugo/Toal).Highly recommend. 5 out of 5 stars.

Posted: July 4, 2015
												Good combat and a fair story are the strong points of this game.Extremely linear progression and the fact that you are confined to a tower for pretty much all of the play are it's cons.You play as three characters (a playthrough for each, one being unlockable after finishing with one of the other two) through the story mode to unravel their story as they ascend the demon tower, battling monsters and large bosses along the way. The story itself is fair, with some expected plot twists (and some not so expected) but doesn't have that much in the funny side. Everyone seems more into serious business mode. So if you want something with laughs this isn't really the game.Combat is real time, meaning that for the most part your skill at dodging attacks will determine your success, mostly in the harder difficulties. You don't get healing items nor healing magic either but some enemies drop use-on-pickup items. Some heal, some boost a stat for a time, and there's also currency drops you use to buy upgrades. A gripe I have is that the items and currency are dropped pretty much everywhere when killing monsters and because they disappear over time, you sometimes have to choose between clearing the room or pausing to run around to grab the spread items. Each character has basic attacks, including jump and jump attacks, and obtain magic items through the game that allow them to use special abilities used mainly for battle but are sometimes needed to get past certain parts of the game. There's no puzzles here either so most of the time you are either in combat or reading the story.Speaking of sounds, there's no voice acting here and the music is pretty much midi based. In fact all sounds remind me of the final 16 bit (SuperNES) to early 32 bit (PS1) era games so don't expect a John Williams score here.Visuals are the same. Characters and common enemies are all sprite based(they do have beautiful portraits), while the stage and bosses use very low polygon models, akin to PSP games. Sprites are drawn in the chibi style while portraits use the usual serious anime way. The one complain I have about the visuals is that the whole game takes place in a tower where all rooms are similar in terms of textures and such, only changing their color every few stages. Sure, no room is the same and there's plenty of enemies to get you busy, but I myself like variety of backdrops and open spaces. Then again hard to do when the premise of the game is to explore a big round demon tower.Overall it's a good game I can recommend to throw yourself back with a simple yet effective gameplay, simple visuals that while similar, don't completely bore in my opinion, and a good story to boot.

Posted: November 5, 2013
												Live the legend that is Ys in Ys: Origin. Search through a sprawling and multi tiered tower that you may remember from other Ys games for the first time on a quest to find the twin goddesses and thwart demons and outsiders alike. While easier and much more linear than others in the series, this game provides multiple characters with different playstyles and controls the same as modern Ys installments for fast and decisive action. A gloriously atmospheric and rocking soundtrack supports the different zones of the tower while monsterous and menacing bosses bar your path to your ultimate goal of rescuing the goddesses. The various ways to complete this game depending on what character you pick through their combat style makes this game very replayable if you are a fan of Ys or real-time action RPGs. Through the use of magic artifacts and different weapons you are able to find unique weaknesses in enemies and exploit them viciously. While your equipment is very limited for a Ys game, the items you can pick up are mostly the ones you know and love from other installments as they are recovered from the broken land of Ys here initially. I never had a Ys game before Oath, but with this, I and II (remade with the old "bump" combat style), and Oath as well in my library I always keep coming back to Ys for another adventure.

Posted: July 24, 2012
												Great game. The combination of lightning fast combat and perfectly balanced difficulty means that every level gained, item upgraded, or new item found will dramatically improve your chances in the glorious boss battles.It may not be a deep game in terms of upgrade paths or character customization, but  its focus means that every moment, every boss battle is wonderfully tuned.Multiple characters (with different stories for each), time attack mode, and some challenging achievements offer extra content beyond a single dungeon run, but even without them this game is more than worth the asking price.

Posted: July 31, 2013
												If you enjoy playing action role-playing games (particularly those from Japan), Ys Origin is a solid investment.  At first, the level designs and monsters were fairly basic, but this is not so much of an issue as you progress higher up the tower.  The amount of variety in the demon designs and floor designs later on isn't spectacular, but keep in mind this is all going on inside of a tower.  The bosses--I would say--are the only exception.  The level and skill system revolve around finding new equipment and gems.  Although simple in design, there is just enough variety to keep you interested.  The story itself is alright (at least to the point where I am at...), and the characters aren't too bad.  You won't be interacting with them too much anyway.  In order to improve your character's own abilities and the abilities of some of your weapons and other equipment, the game allows players to cash in the SP dropped by defeated demons.  This SP is cashed in at the game's Goddess statues, which also serve as save points.  Generally, the distance between these save points is just the "right" distance.  If you don't know what difficulty to play at, I would recommend the "normal" difficulty setting.  Normal might seem too easy at first, but the game becomes significantly harder later on.  However, action RPG veterans will likely want to bump up the difficulty a notch or two.  If not at the normal price, then consider adding Ys Origin to your Steam library the next time the game is on sale.

Posted: December 28, 2012
												If you've played "Ys: The Oath in Felghana", this is very similar, except this game is a bit more polished in a lot of ways. Origin has a lot more content, the graphic design is mostly the same but it still looks better, the music seems slightly higher quality (though a bit less metal than TOiF has). This game is more linear than TOiF, but it doesn't really feel like it because the story is far superior to TOiF and the level design is very good. There is a lot of content, with multiple characters and stories to play through and you can unlock boss rush, time attack, and battle arenas, and you can even purchase bonus stuff from earning SP in the arenas. Origin is much bigger than TOiF in many ways. Both are good games, but this one is the better of the two.I did notice a couple graphical errors when at a 1080p res, being that a few skyboxes/backgrounds left black space on the right side of the screen. It really wasn't a big deal though, and I think it only happened in two parts of the game.Rating: 7.8/10Worth: $5 to $12.50

Posted: January 12, 2015
												Well damn, having almost never played a single RPG game, and JRPG nonetheless, this game caught my attention when it was on anime sale on steam. Why did I buy this and the other Ys games on steam on a whim like that even if they were on sale? Why did my curiosity get the better of me? And why this urge to play this game non-stop?Soo many questions, and only one answer: "This game is an epic RPG with a decent (though perhaps anime-cliche) story with a really fun and very much replayable game-play that takes you on a journy inside a demon tower. Very simplistic in its setup, but my god the best part is the boss battles. Well designed requiring more than just skills but also a certain strategy, makes it less easier than killing simple masses of enemies in comparison. This is probably one of the best non-turn based and non-party JRPG games out there. And that goes for the whole series, as I assume the original games are even better story-wise. Either way, if you're into RPG games or just like anime or japanese related stuff like me, then surely this is a good game to try out. would give 9/10 gg wp

Posted: January 11, 2015
												This game is loads of fun. Combat is smooth and rewarding, not too complicated but it's not just buttonmashing either. The platforming is done very well, challenging but not frustrating. Bosses are awesome (as far as I've gotten). Only niggle (ugh, really steam? I'm saying n.i.g.g.l.e) is if you're really having trouble with a boss, it may be you're just underleveled. The game doesn't really emphasize your level so it's easy to miss, but I found that after going back and gaining 4 levels, the boss that was seriously kicking my behind, was suddenly pretty easy (although you'll still need to learn each boss' attackpatterns). Luckily though, grinding those 4 levels was very quick, probably no more than half an hour or so, and didn't feel like traditional grinding (aka boring) at all.One comment though, everyone's saying how tough the game is... Well, it's not easy, but you might think it's a frustrating experience. As far as I'm concerned it's not. It offers a challenge, but it never feels unfair and to me personally on normal mode I find it's just right (and I'm not normally a glutton for punishment, still havent dared to start up dark soulds ;-))I haven't gotten anywhere near completing this game yet, but just wanted to share this quick review because the game is still on sale for another 21 hours or so. So what are you waiting for? Go buy it!

Posted: July 9, 2014
												I made a Let's Play from it. I think this is worth it.There are a lot of games in the Ys series, several of which are on Steam. This is actually a prequel, set hundreds of years before the main series games.Yet... this is my favorite.The Ys series are action RPGs. What makes them unique is that a level-up should not be underestimated - it makes the difference between getting served by a boss and dominating it. So grinding feels genuinely rewarding, and something you shouldn't have to do much of if you're not playing on higher levels. Plus, the soundtrack absolutely rocks.There is a bit of a Metroid feel as you'll be backtracking and searching around for powerups to help you get further into the tower. There are three characters, and for me the game was never really boring enough not to replay with the other characters. Getting all achievements, however, requires beating the game a total of six times, and on the highest difficulty for three of them. Don't think I'm going for that.The Ys series was never huge on story - you won't find anything revolutionary here. But it's not a problem, since the gameplay more than makes up for it.In summary: Genuinely fun action, great music, and a great intro into the Ys series. GET THIS GAME.

Posted: August 4, 2012
												This action RPG drips "old-school" from its pores. While the series never caught on big in the US during its original releases, these remakes and rereleases are worth a look.There isn't any variation or customization in your character progression, other than the order in which you buy some passive upgrades, so the game will succeed or fail by the gameplay itself. It mostly succeeds here, if you liked Secret of Mana and similar games. There's a great soundtrack to keep you going as well.So what's old-school about it? Two things stand out: the punishing bosses and the level grind. You'll NEED to pick out the boss patterns to beat them. If you're not stopping to spill some extra blood as you play through the game, you'll be underleveled and you will die quickly. This can even happen on normal monsters - if you find yourself dealing weaksauce damage to new monsters, when you used to be cleaving through armies, go back and grind a few levels. Comparative level matters a lot.

Posted: April 16, 2013
												The Ys (prounounced Ees) series has long ben one of the finer series in Japanese action RPGs. It has been known for being one of the first game series to emphasize story, its brutal bosses,   fantastic rock soundtrack.....and barely ever being imported into the U.S. My own only experience with the series was Ys III, released in 1991, on the Sega GenesisYs Origins is a surprisingly polished game, considering its original release in 2006. With a focus on combat and dungeon exploration, the game feels familiar, but is polished enough to stay entertained enough through its campaign.And what a campaign. Though a single character's story line is no longer than 8 to 9 hours, Ys Origins provides 3 different characters, each with a completely different fighting style, viewpoint in the story, and even differences in area accessability and boss battles. Combined with bonus time attack and boss rush modes, where devoted players can earn special costumes, battles, and even a bonus character, Ys Origin can easily be enjoyed for over 30 hours. Ys Origin is not without flaws. The story is serviceable, but fairly predictable. Some later boss battles can be an exercise in frustration, and you'll wish that they mixed up the dungeons a bit more between characters. However, for anyone looking for a classic, rewarding, challenging action RPG with all of the Japanese trappings, you can do a lot worse than this artifact of the previous decade.

Posted: August 18, 2012
												A solid piece of hack-and-slash platformery (is that even a word?)  with rpg elements thrown in. The graphics leave a little to be desired- I recommend watching the trailer to see if they're your cup of tea- and the story is a tad cliche, but that doesn't stop Ys Origin from being a fun-filled romp. The adjustable difficulty levels make the game accessible to casual gamers and hardcore fans alike, and the multiple character choices make this game more replayable than the previous Ys title released on Steam, Oath in Felghana. In fact, if you want to see what the Ys series is all about, this is a good game to start with. A word of caution for the uninitiated- the boss fights are old-school, learn-how-this-thing-can-kill-me-by-dying -to-it-repeatedly encounters, especially on any difficulty above easy; then again, the boss encounters are part of the game- and the series'- charm. Is it an amazingly designed game, worthy of critical accolades? No. Is it enjoyable? Definitely.

Posted: December 11, 2014
												If you are already a Falcom fan, then I don't need to encourage you more to go play it. Ys Origin brings you the tale of 700 years before the first game. The epic conflict you had in the first game is finally revealed, and what a Hell of a start it is. In terms of story it stands strong, and playing between each character may cause the game to feel repeatable, but it's actually done well. The gameplay may feel a bit stiff or slippery from time to time, but that's because Ys wasn't made to be this combo-ish action game; Adol isn't in it though, so I think that's where the problem lies. It's easy to get to the 100% clearing, but for 100% upgrades you really need to have a love for grinding. And as always in true Ys fashion, if you think this game isn't hard enough there is the Hellish "Nightmare" mode. It offers enough variety for you to play on and a loveable story. Though it may look weird from a linair look, this being Ys 0, the gap of 700 years should indicate that this one will stand on its own like it should be.

Posted: August 17, 2013
												DOUBLE REWRITEMetroidvania-style platforming with a deeply-involving story? YES.It takes a lot of patience to understand the entire detail of the first story between the first two characters (Yunica and Hugo) in their own perspectives, but understanding it is as rewarding as beating it at higher difficulties -- well worth the effort. But once you complete the game with both of those, you get a new character -- Toal -- and the real story begins. It's difficult to understand like before, but once you figure it out, it's excellent.Yunica is a melee character; Hugo is a ranged character. Toal is a melee character, but his Boost mode turns him into a demon -- crucial for certain areas of the game. Some monsters take more damage to specific elements -- remember this.And don't forget to buckle up.

Posted: February 15, 2015
												Fans of the Ys Series, rejoice in learning the origin of the legends which the first two games are based off of. The game primarily revolves around either Yunica Tovah or Hugo Fact, and yes, those family names should be familiar to those who've played the first two games. Each of them plays differently, with some mechanics making some fights a lot easier than others, some more difficult.This game serves as the seventh canonical entry in the Ys series (Ys V is non-canon), and as a prequel to the entire series. It does a lot to explain a lot of the lore in the first two games, as well as why even in the main series, there is always a seemingly world ending threat around the corner.The game has three characters, two of which are available from the start: Yunica Tovah and Hugo Fact. The third is unlockable after beating the game with either one and finishes the story with its true ending. Even if you don't beat it with him, there is still a lot that is canon from Yunica and Hugo's endings, just not the true mastermind, a very familiar enemy who was responsible for the events in Ys I & II.Killing normal enemies is rather easy, and if you are having trouble, go back to a previous zone and grind a couple of levels, then come back. You will easily know when you've grinded enough in a zone when the experience rewards vs. the amount needed to level becomes more grindy than the time needed is worth. Basically, if you need to level, you can gain   a level in about 10 - 15 minutes, sooner if you're on the low side for the zone.Still, the main focus is the bosses. Each has unique mechanics and weaknesses that you need to take into account. Don't be surprised if you die a few times figuring out the boss, and if your attention slips, or you make a wrong move, then you are in for a world of hurt. That's where the fun is.

Unlike most games where a death to a difficult boss would be frustrating; I never wanted to quit, as every death got me more pumped up than the last.The smooth flow of the game wasn't everything. This games soundtrack took me by storm, as I am a sucker for a game's soundtrack. One amazing song after another... This game never grew dull even for a second. The fact that i have written over 20 words about this game should explain just how much I enjoyed it because I hate reading... and writing... and typing.....Basically what I'm trying to say is this game is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome, and now has a place in my list of favourite games. :D

Posted: December 24, 2014
												I didn't know what to expect when I bought this game, but I've enjoyed it immensely.  The gameplay is somewhat reminiscent of the older Zelda games, and it's very, very fast-paced.  The graphics are definitely showing their age (the game was originally published in Japan in 2006 or so), but don't really detract from an otherwise enjoyable experience.This has been one of my favorite recent purchases.  I hope XSEED is able to publish English translations of more stuff like this and Oath in Felghana (which is also fun, but not quite as good).Pros:-Fast paced, fun gameplay-Interesting bosses-Can reduce the difficulty of boss encounters by grinding a bit to raise character level (good if you're as bad at the boss fights as I am)-Although grinding is necessary, there's an XP multiplier based on the number of hits you've made in the last few seconds, so it's possible to grind more quickly by fighting only in crowded rooms-Responsive controls-Good soundtrack-Pretty good replay value--although the levels are all the same, each of the three playable characters has their own story arc with slight variations in the boss sequence and various other details-Very good localization work by XSEED; doesn't feel rushed at all-Runs very smoothly on modern hardwareCons:-Graphics a bit stale-Long cutscenes and dialog that cannot be skipped (note: there IS an option in the settings applet which suppresses ALL video playback; good for skipping the intro on a second play-through)-Character level scaling is very drastic:  Gaining two levels is usually sufficient to turn an unwinnable encounter into a cakewalk, so this tends to inspire a decent amount of grinding-You NEED to find all items, particularly weapon power-ups; there are some enemies that are virtually impervious to damage if your weapon is at too low a level.

Posted: December 27, 2013
												Even though Ys Origin is now a relatively old game (it was first released by the end of 2006), it still has plenty to offer to RPG fans:   - Beautiful graphics, both in-game and cutscenes   - Simple and intuitive graphic user interface   - Very fun, rewarding, fast-paced action that hardly gets old   - Challenging bosses that will make you rethink your playing strategy   - Not one, nor two... but three different game stories that seemly complement each otherDefinitely a great introduction to the Ys series and great improvement from the previously released title, The Oath in Felghana, except maybe in the soundtrack which in my humble opinion lacked that trilling component that made me want to carry on shredding monsters just to keep hearing the track. However, this is more than compensated by the deeply intriguing game stories; more than once I found myself playing an extra hour just to find out what was going to happen next.Overall, even if you're one of those players that rush through games (which I highly discourage with this one), Ys Origin is guaranteed to give you a good 30+ hours of gameplay any noteworthy action RPG should.

Posted: September 4, 2014
												I rarely finish games, but I finished Ys Origin twice and almost went for a third do-over.The game as its core is quite fun. Mash Z at baddies. Baddies come straight at you, pushing you towards progress. Build that experience multiplier with every hit. Room emptied? Quick, rush to the next one, don't let it fade away! Mash, mash, hack and slash! Faster, Yunica, faster!The part where the game forces you to essentially stop having fun mashing enemies to pieces are decidedly the least fun, and the very first chapter is probably the worst in this regard.For the rest, however, the game doesn't look upon you for pushing recklessly forward: the game recognizes that there is nothing wrong with W+M1 (or, rather, Z+↑); it embraces the euphoria you get by building up your attack chain and going from monster to monster, building up buffs in the progress, leveling up without a break -- there is none of that "YOU JUST GOT ONE SKILL POINT STOP EVERYTHING YOU ARE DOING AND SPEND IT RIGHT THE HELL NOW" stuff, and the upgrades you CAN buy can wait in between flurries. Hell: the way NPCs in the game described Yunica in their fixed scripts matched perfectly the way I was playing -- accidental Z-mashing-based rolepaying has no right feeling this rewarding.You spend 10 hours finishing the game, and you feel rewarded and spent and awesome. And then the game says you've unlocked a new character.This is where I usually tune out; I don't really tend to do NG+s with rare exceptions. Ys Origin however was just so much fun it earned a chance for one, and oh boy. This new character's plot is completely different from Yunica's; it feels like the sequel to the story, or rather, a better version of it; and indeed my understanding is that it's this second version of the story that gets picked up in the next games.The way he plays, also, is like Yunica squared: for a few boss fights, Yunica could rely on long range attacks to keep safe, but this second character has no ranged options at all. He must get in close and personal and it feels rewarding as hell, even though I've actually been playing on easy throughout -- it's still a game from Japan and I do NOT trust their sense of scale when it comes to difficulty.I enjoyed Ys Origin a lot and it's almost a pit that the third character's plot doesn't seem different enough to warrant a third replay.Get it, get the cards and get smashing.

Posted: August 26, 2014
												So, what is it you want from a game? Pretty visuals? An excellent story? Intense action? A challenge? If the answer to the last two questions are "yes", you should try this game. The anime/JRPG style visuals may not be everyone's cup of tea, so take that into account. The story is by no means bad, but nothing that'll keep you at the edge of your seat. But there are some really good reasons why to play this game. First of all, the gameplay. Fast-paced and fluid hack&slash action typical for an ARPG with the difference that it has a vertical dimension as well, adding some platforming to the whole concept. Initially you get to pick between two characters, and can unlock a third one. The story remains more or less the same (it's best described as 3 different points of view), but there are significant differences in how the characters are played, each of the 3 offers a unique gameplay experience. You can pick either a controller or the KB/mouse duo, both work just fine. The configuration tool is user-friendly and offers a lot of freedom in defining your desired configuration.There are five difficulty levels, ranging from "very easy" to "nightmare". The game is quite challenging, don't be shy to try it on a lower difficulty if you just don't seem to move forward. The strongest point of this game are the numerous and intense boss-battles, which test your reflexes and wits alike. You won't get anywhere with the "hit it until it stops moving" idea even on "very easy". Expect to hit the retry button numerous times, sometimes it's not obvious what you need to do from the start. Explore and experiment, it's fun! Finished story mode with all 3 characters? The game still has replay value! In the Time Attack mode, you can test your mettle against the game's bosses without having to replay the whole game again. And it doesn't end there. While Time attack can be played right after completing the game with one character, once you clear the story mode with all 3, you gain access to Arena Mode, where you fight waves of enemies from the level of your choice and collect SP (the game's currency) to unlock bonus content. The soundtrack is simply amazing. Masterpiece after masterpiece, greatly adding to the enjoyment the game has to offer.If "challenge" is your middle name, then you shouldn't miss this game.The verdict: 8.9/10

Faster, Yunica, faster!The part where the game forces you to essentially stop having fun mashing enemies to pieces are decidedly the least fun, and the very first chapter is probably the worst in this regard.For the rest, however, the game doesn't look upon you for pushing recklessly forward: the game recognizes that there is nothing wrong with W+M1 (or, rather, Z+↑); it embraces the euphoria you get by building up your attack chain and going from monster to monster, building up buffs in the progress, leveling up without a break -- there is none of that "YOU JUST GOT ONE SKILL POINT STOP EVERYTHING YOU ARE DOING AND SPEND IT RIGHT THE HELL NOW" stuff, and the upgrades you CAN buy can wait in between flurries. Hell: the way NPCs in the game described Yunica in their fixed scripts matched perfectly the way I was playing -- accidental Z-mashing-based rolepaying has no right feeling this rewarding.You spend 10 hours finishing the game, and you feel rewarded and spent and awesome. And then the game says you've unlocked a new character.This is where I usually tune out; I don't really tend to do NG+s with rare exceptions. Ys Origin however was just so much fun it earned a chance for one, and oh boy. This new character's plot is completely different from Yunica's; it feels like the sequel to the story, or rather, a better version of it; and indeed my understanding is that it's this second version of the story that gets picked up in the next games.The way he plays, also, is like Yunica squared: for a few boss fights, Yunica could rely on long range attacks to keep safe, but this second character has no ranged options at all. He must get in close and personal and it feels rewarding as hell, even though I've actually been playing on easy throughout -- it's still a game from Japan and I do NOT trust their sense of scale when it comes to difficulty.I enjoyed Ys Origin a lot and it's almost a pit that the third character's plot doesn't seem different enough to warrant a third replay.Get it, get the cards and get smashing.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												Ys Origins is the very first of the series (in Ys timeline, not by release date) and sets the stage for the rest of the games.The gameplay is somewhat like the Legend of Zelda/Alundra (for those who had played this game back in the era of the PS1) with the addition of a basic leveling system.The story plays out over the course of 2 character, in which you choose to play through one of those character's storyline and after finishing, can go back and play the other (as well as the 3rd character after you complete the game with one of the first two playable characters). Posted: December 29, 2013
												"Ys Origin is a Japanese action role-playing game developed and published by Nihon Falcom for Microsoft Windows in 2006." (Wikipedia, November 2013)I've played this RPG for 45 hours on the hardest of the 5 difficulties (nightmare, hard, normal, easy, very easy) with "Hugo" (1 of 3 characters) and completed it by level 52. I found the story to be a run-of-the-mill "good guy wants power, turns evil temporarily, and repents through the power of friendship/love". I'm generally not the type of guy to delve into, and enjoy, the story of a game very much anyways, so I didn't mind it. In fact, considering that I look for "great gameplay" in games, and what type of gameplay I'll tend to go for, I would practically expect a story to be "the usual" in a game (not to say I haven't enjoyed original stories). I don't know how the story goes with the other 2 characters, since I haven't played them yet.This game, played with a top-down camera angle, plays kinda like a shooter when Hugo is the chosen character, as his attacks revolve around shooting magic missiles straight ahead of him. After a quick test run, the other 2 characters appear to revolve around close-range melee combat. On the hardest difficulty level, the bosses offer such a challenge that you'll find yourself grinding a lot, just to gain that extra level or two and be able to defeat the boss at all (and even then, your battle strategy better be near perfect). This game has some simple puzzle-solving, if you can even call it that. You'll find yourself having to press buttons, defeat certain enemies, obtain and use items/skills, and so on. I did enjoy the challenging gameplay, but it would get frustrating at times with bosses, and also 1 time with a certain enemy that can practically insta-kill you (but that you'll still have to deal with). The only thing to do there is keep looking around for equipment and the like, and grind in special spots to gain levels.If you want to know how nice the graphics look, just "You-Google-Tube" some gameplay footage on the game. And while you're at it, check out the soundtrack for it as well. It's pretty awesome. As of this post, the game is normally $19.99 USD on Steam and I'd say it's worth the price if you love to spend many hours on a challenging "battle-grind" RPG. If it turns-out that you love the game, then you may also love "Ys: The Oath in Felghana", which follows a similar gaming style. You may want to avoid Ys I & II though, which has your main attack revolve around ramming into enemies (like in Hydlide), which ruins any sense of "gameplay" (at least in my opinion).

Posted: November 24, 2014
												Probably the quickest I've ever gone from demo to purchase.As Ys tends to go, it's a ballbuster, but a damn fun one.  Combat is surprisingly flexible for its simplicity.  The set piece boss fights are creative, complex, and completely unforgiving, but for the most part tuned very well -- a player who's practiced up can take them down reliably and feel like a total badass in the process.  Experience gain is tuned to scale based on the level difference between you and your opponent, so you catch up very quickly when underleveled but can always crank out an extra level for an edge against something.There are exceptions, of course.  Kishgal is capable of randomly screwing you depending on which moves he does in succession, and a couple bosses (Gelaldy, Pictimos) are long and tedious enough to stop feeling fun after the first half of their HP bar.  The latter third of the game is extremely melee-unfriendly, and poor Yunica is largely reduced to spamming one special attack.

Posted: October 3, 2014
												I absolutely love this game. As many have already have said, there are two characters to play as initially, with a third being unlocked after you beat the game with either of the first two. I recommend playing the game at least three times, once with each character. The order I played in was: Yunica (close/medium-range), Hugo (medium/long-range), then the secret character (very close-range). All three have interwining stories, and you only get the full picture after beating the game with all three. The story itself is interesting, and makes you want to keep playing long after the credits roll. The good thing about Ys Origin is that you don't need any backstory from the previous games, due to this title being a prequel to the rest of the series. The combat is addictive, with the environments and enemies changing often enough so as not to get repetitive. The soundtrack is sublime, and will make you want to listen to it even outside of the game.I played the game on Normal difficulty, and doing so will probably net you 8-10 hours of game for each character. However, I recommend playing on Hard, because grinding even a little bit on Normal will make the game obscenely easy. Overall, if you like action-RPGs, a great soundtrack, and a great story, you can't go wrong with this one.

I could go on and on in an in-depth analysis of this game, but I will keep it short and simple: if you want a good story and challenge, Ys Origin is your game.
