Posted: August 19, 2015
 Note 1: This is currently being played on Nightmare difficulty. That being said, your mileage may vary on how these games compare (how easy is is to make money, gain exp, etc.) Note 2: I will be comparing this to Oath in Felghana's gameplay. Spoilers for both games will be unmarked, so please read at your discretion.      This is a review of the game from a technical/gameplay standpoint  not  a review regarding the storyline, graphics, etc. I am writing this review for those that wish to play the Ys games in chronological order.      For those of you that don't know, Origin, Oath in Felghana, and Ark of Napishtim use the same engine. However, OiF and Origin were released after Ark of Napishtim, in that order, and thus were "tweaked" or "improved," rather, in terms of combat, stat growth, and money gain. Playing in chronological order means playing Origin, then Oif, then Ark, and getting used to things that might be missing, as you go through the series.      Now, I've played Origin all the way through on all characters on Nightmare difficulty, and the first thing to compare between Origin and Oif, is that Yunica and Adol play similarly to each other, without being exactly the same. For example, while Yunica and Adol's fire spells function identically, Yunica gets her fire magic from a sword, which does slightly more damage than her normal weapon, but swings slower. Other than that, their attack patterns are pretty similar, with Adol doing more thrusting as opposed to Yunica swinging her axe about (which makes sense, considering you don't stab with it).      In Origin, your dash attack has a chance of lowering the enemy's defence, including bosses. This is incredibly helpful as it can be chained into your normal combo. In OiF, you still have a dash attack, however, instead of lowering the enemy's defence, it is a quick 3-hits, that can be chained into your normal combo. That being said, in Origin, it's imperative to learn how to effectively use your dash attack, where as in OiF, you can almost completely disregard it, and get by just fine.      The second thing to note, OiF and Origin have a thing called Boost, which functions similar to a Limit Break, if you will; while it's active, movement and attack speed is increased, while damage is greatly reduced. However, Origin added an additional power to that, called Burst, a special attack that, when activated, will use the remaining time on your Boost. The attack varies for each character, but is nice to have, as it's essentially a panic button, to go along with your Limit Break. You don't  need  it, but it's nice to have, in the situations where you are surrounded by enemies with 3 HP, and no way out.      Regarding the difficulty as a whole, of both games, Nightmare is incredibly hard, even frustrating at times, in both Origin and OiF. The difference, however, is that OiF has boss fights that are much more demanding in terms of snap decisions, timing, and reflexes, whereas the dungeons leading up to said fights, are a fun challange. Not particularly terrifying or anything. The first boss, Ellefale, is both a perfect representation of what to expect later on, as well as being a nice throwback to Ys 2, where everything died by fire. If you try to dodge her attacks too early, they will chace after you, and you'll get hit, and likewise, dodge too late, and you get hit. For a first boss, having to learn the timing right then and there is incredibly demanding, especially when you die in 2 or 3 hits. Boss fights like Gyalva and Gildias very much felt the same way, requiring precise timing, quick thinking, and not using every tool in your arsenal will cost you your life.      On the other hand, Origin had much harder dungeons, yet had less demanding boss fights (not to say that they aren't exactly "harder"). I found myself dying quite a bit, as trash mobs used their numbers and large attack power to hit for all I'm worth. The Water Prison has you fighting enemies that can only be destroyed with your earth power, while trying to navigate underwater, looking for more oxygen. The Silent Desert has enemies that, when you first get there, can't be permanantly killed, all the while traversing quicksand, while they come from the ground and dance around you. At times, I felt myself traversing these dungeons with a sense of caution, as the next batch of enemies, and a wrong move would be the end of me. While poor planning will also get you killed in dungeons in OiF, it felt a lot more frequent in Origin.      Boss fights, however, were a lot more fair. The dodging you had to do from enemy's attacks would prepare you for this moment, because a lot of the bosses have projectiles, or attacks that reach large sections of the field. Jenocres' attacks feel very much like playing a shoot 'em up, for example. Which leads to one of the more noticible changes between Origin and OiF; You see the entire battlefield, and always have eyes on the boss, at all times. During the course of the fight, lightning strikes will come down in the area where you are standing, indicated by circles on the ground. You have to keep running, until the lightning is finished chasing you. Being able to see where  Jenocres is, as well as the entire arena, while dodging attacks that reach every corner of the screen is keeps you from running into another attack, after dodging the last one.      This, cannot be said for OiF. With the exception of Gildias and Ellefale, you do not normally have constant sight on the boss, the entire arena, and Adol, at the same time, without keeping within a certain distance of the boss. The arena in which you fight is about the same average size as the ones in Origin, however, the camera is focused on Adol, zoomed out for the boss fight. What this means is that to see all of the boss's tells and attacks before they happen, you must keep within a certain proximity. However, the result of that is a smaller margin of error for dodging and reacting to attacks.      To compensate for the lack of traditional shops, Origin has a system implemented where you can buy powers, named Blessings, which allow your character active passives such as boosted ailment resistance, reduced damage from terrain, or things such as increased item drop rate. However, on Nightmare, all SP (the currency of the game) is worth 1 SP. With the occasional treasure chest giving SP, you will have just enough SP throughout the game to increase the defence on your armour, and obtain 1 to 2 extra skills, depending on what you get, and assuming you are leveling normally. The lack of shops also means that you will find all of your weapons and armour, and any items you obtain must either be found, or otherwise obtained from the story. OiF does not suffer from this, as it does use the traditional shop. You do still find weapons and armour during your escapades, however, you can also buy weapons, armour, and expendable items. Thankfully, unlike in Origin, currency in the land of Felghana is a lot easier to come by, so there is no worrying about saving for just the right moment.      Upgrading weapons and armour requires two things: money, and Cleria Ore. In OiF, ore comes in abundance, dropped by enemies, along with gold. Every weapon and piece of armour requires both gold, and ore to level up (stat increase), with better equipment being more expensive. Origin has simplified this process, in accordance with the shop system and/or money drop rates. Weapons are upgraded specifically with Cleria Ore, however, they are scattered throughout the game, and power up your weapon enough to last you until the next upgrade, and armour is upgraded by spending SP.

Posted: January 23, 2013
												<3 Glad I got into this series..  LOVE THE GAME IS A MUST HAVE

Posted: March 14, 2016
												The more I immerse myself in the Ys series, the more enamored I become.  This is one solid little franchise.  There are so many things that Falcom does right in caring for this classic property, and I have high hopes for future Ys games I will be playing.  This is yet another perfect little charming gem of an action RPG.  It mixes 2D sprite animation and seamless 3D architecture to create a style both retro and timeless.  The care and attention payed to the characters, story, music, and ys heritage is truly admirable.Design wise, this game is a typical dungeon crawl, but the challenge is quite thrilling during boss fights.  The exploration aspect can get a bit tedious if you play through the game multiple times in quick succession, but I imagine this can be offset by tweaking difficulty levels to your liking. On that note, the story of Ys Origin plays out with a Roshamon style redundancy; with three individual character's story-lines.  Much of the joy of this game comes from experiencing the events of the narrative from these different perspectives.  Granted, there are slight differences in each Character's narrative, with only one (Claw's) considered 'cannon', but walking through the game in each of their shoes lets you become much more familiar with the characters and the world in which they live.  I can't imagine having only played through this game with a single character, and I found each separate run interesting and challenging due to the different play mechanics.  It's a faithful loveletter to the Lore Falcom has developed for Ys over the last several decades.  The characters, the settings, and even the music is heavily inspired by past games in the franchise.  Now at the time of this writing, I had managed to play the steam releases of Ys 1&2, as well as Oath in Felghana (remake of ys 3).  These games stand perfectly fine on their own story wise, and it is absolutely unnecessary for anyone to have any prior knowledge of the franchise to get your money's worth.  That being said, each entry also helps to paint a beautifully detailed picture of a larger whole.  Falcom seem quite devoted to the world they've created, and the relationship between games is actually quite nuanced.  I'm so very glad I played through this, and I encourage everyone to take it for a spin.  If you're only interested in a charming hack 'n slash romp, by all means coast through it.  If you're at all interested in the story of Ys, I very much encourage you to experience each story line.  On the lower difficulties, each play through should take about 8 hours.  I, myself, played the first round on normal, then coasted through the next two on easier settings for a total playtime of 26 hours.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												A prequel to the long-running Ys series, Ys Origins tells the story of Darm Tower before the events of Ys I & II. Unlike most Ys games, you don't play as familiar, red-haired protagonist Adol Christin, but rather one of two characters (there is also a 'secret' third character), the axe-wielding Yunica and the mage Hugo. This is a different take on the series than most entries, and is a welcome change as there is a lot of variety with the playstyles of each character, and this also adds to the replay value as you can play through the game multiple times with different characters, the story being slightly different for each as well. The story is rather bare-bones, but mildly interesting, particularly if you are an Ys fan or a fan of traditional fantasy storylines. Nothing to set the world on fire, but the main characters are likable (particularly Yunica) and the story does not get in the way of the game's main strength: the fast-paced, action-RPG combat. If you've never played an Ys game, particularly the older titles, the game plays as a mix of a top-down hack n' slash and a 2.5 platformer. Many of the skills you gain have dual uses for both platforming and combat, and there is a decent variety of abilities. That being said, there is much more combat than platforming in the game, and while the platforming can be occasionally frustrating, the combat is where the series, and this game in particular, truly shines. Combat requires you to quickly chain together attacks, make smart use of your skills, and avoid enemy attacks by dodging and jumping. Basic enemies are not too difficult, though there is a wide variety of enemy types to fight, all with their different skillsets and strategies. The bosses are the main attraction, being both difficult and surprisingly epic for a game without state-of-the-art graphics. One more thing about this game, and the Ys series as a whole: the music is FANTASTIC! Some of the best videogame music I have ever heard is from this series, and this entry keeps the bar set high. There are quite a few stellar tracks, many of which are boss themes. Overall, I would reccomend this game to any fan of the series, any fan of action RPG's, and any fan of Japanese games. If none of these categories apply to you, then pick this gem up on sale. Trust me, you will not be dissapointed, and maybe you'll become another fan of this underappreciated (but spectacular) series.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												I made a Let's Play from it. I think this is worth it.There are a lot of games in the Ys series, several of which are on Steam. This is actually a prequel, set hundreds of years before the main series games.Yet... this is my favorite.The Ys series are action RPGs. What makes them unique is that a level-up should not be underestimated - it makes the difference between getting served by a boss and dominating it. So grinding feels genuinely rewarding, and something you shouldn't have to do much of if you're not playing on higher levels. Plus, the soundtrack absolutely rocks.There is a bit of a Metroid feel as you'll be backtracking and searching around for powerups to help you get further into the tower. There are three characters, and for me the game was never really boring enough not to replay with the other characters. Getting all achievements, however, requires beating the game a total of six times, and on the highest difficulty for three of them. Don't think I'm going for that.The Ys series was never huge on story - you won't find anything revolutionary here. But it's not a problem, since the gameplay more than makes up for it.In summary: Genuinely fun action, great music, and a great intro into the Ys series. GET THIS GAME.

Posted: November 24, 2016
Ys Origin is an absolutely rock-solid action RPG with a ton of play depth, multiple playable characters, and difficulty levels that make meaningful changes to the gameplay (rather than just modifying damage dealt and received). Even absolute neophytes will be able to clear the game on Very Easy, but every time you go up a level, you have to learn new attack patterns and new ways of dealing with them. The only drawback to the difficulty levels is on the Nightmare difficulty, which pulls the nasty trick of nerfing the XP and SP given by mobs, and turns the game into a long, dull grind.The game opens with two playable characters, and there's a third to be unlocked later. There is also an "extra" version of each of the characters with slightly different abilities, an alternate outfit for Yunica, and an unlockable "arena" mode that pits you against waves of mobs, complete with online cheaterboards if you're curious who can tweak Cheat Engine the most effectively. That's quite a lot of content!Plot-wise, the game is set in the ancient history of Ys, long before the original Ancient Ys Vanished. This means that Origin is the only Ys game not to feature Adol Christin as the main character (he can be unlocked as a bonus character in the arena, but not in story mode). Instead of Adol, the main characters are important members of the priesthood of Ys, as they seek to contain the spread of demonic energy that's destroying their world. If you're familiar with Ys (particularly the original two games, available on Steam as Ys I & II Chronicles +) there will be lots of material here you'll recognize, but the game is perfectly playable without any Ys background at all.It's hard to go wrong with Ys Origin if you like action JRPGs. There's a lot of play here, and it's a good introduction to the elder statesman of the genre.

Posted: February 23, 2016
												Excellent game, hardly any problems to speak of. Would recommend to basically anyone who can still appreciate older style games and who isn't turned off by cheesy japanese storytelling. This game is also very friendly to people with high end PCs, supporting resolutions beyond 1080p and refresh rates beyond 60Hz. The game actually renders very well at higher resolutions, though the character sprites and portraits become somewhat pixelated.Ys Origin is essentially a 3D action platformer in the style of Alundra for PS1, and to some extent the 2D Zelda games. I would compare it to a sped-up Link to the Past. Emphasis is primarily on combat, but also on finding your way through the game. Each area has a few branching sub-areas which you must navigate to find a key to the boss room. This usually involves going through the area until you reack a fork in the road where reaching one end of the fork will activate some switch that will allow you to grab the boss key from the other end of the fork. Combat is very fast and consists of attacking, using special abilities, jumping, and some other moves. You have 3 special abilities that you can use in combat that offer you some mix of damage, utility, and range. The abilities are different for each of the 3 playable characters but serve the same general purpose. Part of the game is figuring out which ability is most effective for the area you are exploring or the enemy you are fighting.The best part about this game is without a doubt the bosses. Every fight throws something completely unexpected, yet refreshingly original at you. Very rarely will you ever go up to a boss and simply whack it until it dies. Almost every boss has a weakness that must be revealed in some way before you get the chance to actually deal damage. And each boss has attacks that you need to dodge in creative ways instead of just running in a circle. I will give the example of what was probably my favorite boss in the game. The boss is basically a centipede where each pair of legs was its own section of body. The way to kill the boss is to destroy each body segment. The challenge lies in the fact that each time you destroy a body segment, it will start spewing poison bombs that explode if left on the ground too long. This severely inhibits your mobility and also throws a lot of extra damage into the mix. Keep in mind the boss is constantly moving, so you not only need to dodge everything, but also catch up to it so you can actually deal damage. By the end of the fight the field is entirely covered in poison bombs and you have to find a way to weave through them, jump on the boss, and kill the last segment before you die. This boss killed me probably 20 times, but it was still a great experience because each time you can make tiny optimizations or notice something new about an attack that will let you avoid it more easily. Though this game actually involves very little actual platforming, the game utilizes 3D space very well. You are constantly moving up and down through the environment which is a nice change from the typical top-down games where everything is just a flat plane. 3D space is even utilized in combat, with airborne enemies that must be taken down with jumping attacks, to boss attacks that can only be dodged by jumping. From my boss example above, the same boss is able to climb on walls, going completely out of your reach. While doing this he will shoot lightning at you, which you must avoid to keep from falling behind. However, you have a special ability that when charged up has a huge vertical range. If you want, you can hit the boss with this move while he is on the wall. This introduces a risk into the fight by letting you hit the boss while he is high up, but you need to come to a stop to use the attack, opening up the possibility of getting hit by the lightning. Many combat moments in the game involes this same sort of risk/reward that weighs more damage against a higher probability of getting hit, which leads me into my next point...This game has no consumable healing items and no way to heal yourself during combat. This is especially relevant during boss fights. You only have one health bar, and you have to kill the boss before he kills you. This makes for very tense fights, knowing that each mistake is permanent, each risk you take is a real risk and can't be immediately undone by healing yourself. These fights are reminiscent of many boss fights in JRPGs where you desperately hope that you can kill the boss before your healers run out of MP. You can't cheese out any boss by spamming healing items each time you take a lot of damage. This game forces you to learn the patterns and exploit the weaknesses of every single boss. The same is true during regular combat, but normal enemies drop health pickups and there is also an accessory in the game that allows you to heal which standing still. Even so, the game sometimes throws extra tough enemies your way, and you are forced to kill the lot of them in one go which can be just as challenging, especially if none of them drop a health pickup. Now for some minor complaints:The game starts throwing really annoying enemies at you late in the game. While I appreciate challening combat where you don't just mash a button until everything dies, these enemies also flat out waste your time either by being extremely resistant to damage or having small, spread out periods of vulnerability.The plot of the game is pretty bottom of the barrel. It's the exact same good vs evil, friendship is power, find your true strength generic japanese crap that we've all heard a million times before. The game isn't quite as cheery as something like Dragon Quest, but you can pretty much predict the exact plot of the game if you've played any other game that follows the same story structure. Here is some stuff that may be good or bad, depending on your tastes:While there are no healing items in the game, you can always just grind levels and become near-invulnerable if you are having trouble with a boss. I would really recomend not doing this, as every boss in the game is beatable in a reasonable amount of tries without this, but it's still possible. Sometimes grinding a bit can really help out, as being underleveled during a boss fight is extremely punishing as you can sometimes be dealing damage in the single digits and taking huge chunks of damage for small mistakes. The game takes place in a tower and only in a tower. This means no towns, you never encounter any new NPCs to talk to, the only "shop" is at save points, and the only way to go is up. This does bring about a few perks as well though. If you like streamlined games with no fluff, this is perfect for you. The tower structure also lends itself to being a game with almost zero backtracking through previous levels. The only times you do this are for quick story progression segments. Overall, this game is great and worth playing at least once, if not multiple times with each playable character. It is very reminiscent of older games that were made by a small team of dedicated devs, and you can tell the game was made with love. If you are already a Ys fan, expect something above and beyond. If not, maybe save this one for last becuase I truly think it is the cream of the crop as far as the PC titles go.

												I want this game to be the first I reccomend because it deserves no less. Ys Origin has it all: adjustable challenge through many different difficulty levels, many different gaming modes, extremely high replay value through the stories of the three main characters, which should be played in this order: Yunica, Hugo and the third char, each one with a more surprising and amazing story than the previous one, reaching the peak with the third char's story, the canon one, that both blows and completes the other two's stories at the same time. So, suck that, Castlevania X; the RPG-platform genre has a new king. To whoever reads this: don't miss this game by any means.

Posted: August 9, 2015
												With its simple 3D environments, beautiful 2d sprite characters and cheesy but epically wonderful music, YS origins reminds me of something that I’d have played on the original PlayStation or the Sega Saturn.  And I mean that as a huge compliment.Caked in classic JRPG atmosphere, simple but lush graphics and addictive arcade style gameplay, YS Origin should yet al the buttons for JRPG fans.  You get a choice of (eventually) 3 characters, all with different playstyles,  and each character follows a different branch of the main story from a slightly different perspective, which means you’ll probably at his for 30 hours to complete all three storylines, which is just enough for this kinda game.  YS forsakes the turn-based combat of most JRPGS for an arcade-action style of button mashing mayhem.  The combat system isn’t very deep, but it’s a hell of a lot of fun in the way that something like Golden Axe or Gauntlet was in the 80s, and magical effects are really beautiful.  However, what really impressed my about YS Origin is the quality of the PC port; its got graphics options galore, has been properly adjusted for PC monitors, supports keyboard and gamepads (go with a gamepad, trust me), and it runs at a constant smooth framerate. Hopefully, Japanese developers will take notice, and this quality of port will become the norm.Fancy a blast down nostalgia lane?  Got an itch for  an action JRPG with simple but addictive gameplay?  Give this a try.

Posted: September 13, 2015
												Excellent game.Really, I usually find something to nitpick at, but with Ys Origin, it's darn near impossible, since it's such a solid, satisfying title.STORYLINE: 3/5It's got an entertaining, although kind of cliche, anime-like storyline, that's enough to keep you feeling that you're actually making progress as you play. Nothing out of ordinary here, but not bad either.CONTROLS: 5/5It has fantastic controls. I just finished my first playthrough and started my second one (with another character) using an xbox controller and it plays just awesome. Responsive action, simple, yet rewarding controls. Maybe that's the best part of the whole game, it sounds kind of silly, but it just feels good to control the characters as you go. In a simple sentence: the game just feels amazing on your thumbs as you play.GRAPHICS: 4/5Pretty cool graphics that remind me of PS1's RPG games: anime-like portraits, Ragnarok like sprites, pretty good, overall. The in game effects (such as explosions and fire) are just okay, but the cutscenes are pretty good and nicely rendered.GAMEPLAY: 5/5A simple, intuitive item/level system, with very few choices to make. Reminds me a little of how DMC deals with this kind of thing: you get stronger as the enemies get stronger (no choices in stats), and your weapons compose a little, but handful, arsenal, which you'll have to switch around to get through various enemies/situations. I usually like this kind of system, since it gets me more focused on the gameplay, not on the mechanics, but I do feel they could have done with a little more variety, ability wise. Still, solid system, which absolutely doesn't get frustrating as you go (i.e. no grinding absolutely required, at least on normal dificulty playthroughs).SOUND FX and MUSIC: 3/5Music is pretty cool too, although a bit repetitive. Sound effects are what you'd expect from this kind of game, adds to the good feeling you get from hacking at an enemy (could have used the rumble feature on a controller, though).OVERALL:  4/5Overall, I give this game a solid 4 out of 5 score. It's not a Steam MUST PLAY, but you definitely won't regret going through a couple of playthroughs. If you like old school PS1 RPGs and don't mind (or actually prefer) having little to no control over your character's status and are rather just there for the fun of the combat, I DEFINITELY recommend you get this one.

Posted: July 30, 2016
												This game is a whole lot of fun but it is at its core a prequel. All of the significant plot points and character developments rely on the knowledge of Ys I & II, which you can buy on Steam. If you aren't the type to play 2D games then I would highly recommend Ys: The Oath in Felghana instead of Origin. It plays very similarly but has a pretty engaging closed story and is an absolute blast.If you have played Ys I & II then this is the best game in the series. Origin lets you play through the turmoil that seeds the eventual corruption of Ys. You watch how characters are drawn by fate to play certain roles and see the motifs of the later games form. You get three playable characters with their own stories that justify multiple playthroughs, and they greatly expand on the lore surrounding the Fact line. A strong theme throughout the narrative is whether characters are doomed by fate and their lineage, with an underlying theme of elitism and gender discrimination that get resolved by the end of the story. They could have taken more risks but it certainly is engaging and satisfying.The gameplay is fun and fastpaced, with interesting boss battles and a cool story that benefits greatly from knowing what comes before. Pick it up and have fun!

												Ys Origin showed an extremely unique graphic and art style which was extremely foreign to me when I first started the game. Posted: May 10, 2016
												This is, so far, one of the most satisfying action games that I have played in recent years. It is deceptively simple in its mechanisms, but it adds layers of different components and tricks as time goes on.  The gameplay is intense, but strategic. The music is equally intense. The game rewards you the faster you cut down foes by rewarding additional XP per hit, but that counter will decrease as time goes on; this encourages you to keep progressing. The boss-fights are intriguing, and are (deservingly) much more difficult than the enemies around them. This requires a more tactical approach than just mashing buttons; you may end up dead before you can blink if you don't pace yourself.  The platforming elements require timing and focus.Your mileage may vary on a few of these next details, but I think that they are good to note. The game doesn't force you through several of the immersion-breaking and random overworld fetch-quests that can detract from other JRPGs, but at the cost of no overword (that I have seen) to explore. I see it as a pro for this particular game as the world around the tower is a wasteland rather than a varied environment to explore. Due to the facts that the game only appears to take place in a tower, that it is an action game based on a relatively simple to use combat system, and that the game is fast-paced, I suspect that some playing this would tire quickly. Play on Nightmare difficulties for getting the most out of the game: truly exhilarating boss-fights.All in all, an excellent game that I recommend highly.

Posted: August 19, 2015
 Note 1: This is currently being played on Nightmare difficulty. That being said, your mileage may vary on how these games compare (how easy is is to make money, gain exp, etc.) Note 2: I will be comparing this to Oath in Felghana's gameplay. Spoilers for both games will be unmarked, so please read at your discretion.      This is a review of the game from a technical/gameplay standpoint  not  a review regarding the storyline, graphics, etc. I am writing this review for those that wish to play the Ys games in chronological order.      For those of you that don't know, Origin, Oath in Felghana, and Ark of Napishtim use the same engine. However, OiF and Origin were released after Ark of Napishtim, in that order, and thus were "tweaked" or "improved," rather, in terms of combat, stat growth, and money gain. Playing in chronological order means playing Origin, then Oif, then Ark, and getting used to things that might be missing, as you go through the series.      Now, I've played Origin all the way through on all characters on Nightmare difficulty, and the first thing to compare between Origin and Oif, is that Yunica and Adol play similarly to each other, without being exactly the same. For example, while Yunica and Adol's fire spells function identically, Yunica gets her fire magic from a sword, which does slightly more damage than her normal weapon, but swings slower. Other than that, their attack patterns are pretty similar, with Adol doing more thrusting as opposed to Yunica swinging her axe about (which makes sense, considering you don't stab with it).      In Origin, your dash attack has a chance of lowering the enemy's defence, including bosses. This is incredibly helpful as it can be chained into your normal combo. In OiF, you still have a dash attack, however, instead of lowering the enemy's defence, it is a quick 3-hits, that can be chained into your normal combo. That being said, in Origin, it's imperative to learn how to effectively use your dash attack, where as in OiF, you can almost completely disregard it, and get by just fine.      The second thing to note, OiF and Origin have a thing called Boost, which functions similar to a Limit Break, if you will; while it's active, movement and attack speed is increased, while damage is greatly reduced. However, Origin added an additional power to that, called Burst, a special attack that, when activated, will use the remaining time on your Boost. The attack varies for each character, but is nice to have, as it's essentially a panic button, to go along with your Limit Break. You don't  need  it, but it's nice to have, in the situations where you are surrounded by enemies with 3 HP, and no way out.      Regarding the difficulty as a whole, of both games, Nightmare is incredibly hard, even frustrating at times, in both Origin and OiF. The difference, however, is that OiF has boss fights that are much more demanding in terms of snap decisions, timing, and reflexes, whereas the dungeons leading up to said fights, are a fun challange. Not particularly terrifying or anything. The first boss, Ellefale, is both a perfect representation of what to expect later on, as well as being a nice throwback to Ys 2, where everything died by fire. If you try to dodge her attacks too early, they will chace after you, and you'll get hit, and likewise, dodge too late, and you get hit. For a first boss, having to learn the timing right then and there is incredibly demanding, especially when you die in 2 or 3 hits. Boss fights like Gyalva and Gildias very much felt the same way, requiring precise timing, quick thinking, and not using every tool in your arsenal will cost you your life.      On the other hand, Origin had much harder dungeons, yet had less demanding boss fights (not to say that they aren't exactly "harder"). I found myself dying quite a bit, as trash mobs used their numbers and large attack power to hit for all I'm worth. The Water Prison has you fighting enemies that can only be destroyed with your earth power, while trying to navigate underwater, looking for more oxygen. The Silent Desert has enemies that, when you first get there, can't be permanantly killed, all the while traversing quicksand, while they come from the ground and dance around you. At times, I felt myself traversing these dungeons with a sense of caution, as the next batch of enemies, and a wrong move would be the end of me. While poor planning will also get you killed in dungeons in OiF, it felt a lot more frequent in Origin.      Boss fights, however, were a lot more fair. The dodging you had to do from enemy's attacks would prepare you for this moment, because a lot of the bosses have projectiles, or attacks that reach large sections of the field. Jenocres' attacks feel very much like playing a shoot 'em up, for example. Which leads to one of the more noticible changes between Origin and OiF; You see the entire battlefield, and always have eyes on the boss, at all times. During the course of the fight, lightning strikes will come down in the area where you are standing, indicated by circles on the ground. You have to keep running, until the lightning is finished chasing you. Being able to see where  Jenocres is, as well as the entire arena, while dodging attacks that reach every corner of the screen is keeps you from running into another attack, after dodging the last one.      This, cannot be said for OiF. With the exception of Gildias and Ellefale, you do not normally have constant sight on the boss, the entire arena, and Adol, at the same time, without keeping within a certain distance of the boss. The arena in which you fight is about the same average size as the ones in Origin, however, the camera is focused on Adol, zoomed out for the boss fight. What this means is that to see all of the boss's tells and attacks before they happen, you must keep within a certain proximity. However, the result of that is a smaller margin of error for dodging and reacting to attacks.      To compensate for the lack of traditional shops, Origin has a system implemented where you can buy powers, named Blessings, which allow your character active passives such as boosted ailment resistance, reduced damage from terrain, or things such as increased item drop rate. However, on Nightmare, all SP (the currency of the game) is worth 1 SP. With the occasional treasure chest giving SP, you will have just enough SP throughout the game to increase the defence on your armour, and obtain 1 to 2 extra skills, depending on what you get, and assuming you are leveling normally. The lack of shops also means that you will find all of your weapons and armour, and any items you obtain must either be found, or otherwise obtained from the story. OiF does not suffer from this, as it does use the traditional shop. You do still find weapons and armour during your escapades, however, you can also buy weapons, armour, and expendable items. Thankfully, unlike in Origin, currency in the land of Felghana is a lot easier to come by, so there is no worrying about saving for just the right moment.      Upgrading weapons and armour requires two things: money, and Cleria Ore. In OiF, ore comes in abundance, dropped by enemies, along with gold. Every weapon and piece of armour requires both gold, and ore to level up (stat increase), with better equipment being more expensive. Origin has simplified this process, in accordance with the shop system and/or money drop rates. Weapons are upgraded specifically with Cleria Ore, however, they are scattered throughout the game, and power up your weapon enough to last you until the next upgrade, and armour is upgraded by spending SP.

Posted: February 22, 2016
												Ys series in general are not very long and their challenge level is fair with minimal grinding required. This one is a bit of exception in length and challenge, but not as negative aspects. While the length for one character is the average of any other Ys, the replay value lies in the fact there are THREE characters in total, each one with their own play style and emphasizing one aspect or another. And the story also changes itself, showing things that happens with that character while it was not on camera to another, or sometimes fate itself will twist and a whole new situation will unfold.For those seeking for challenge, bosses and enemies can be blazed through in easier difficulties, grinded in average ones, or skillfully fought in later difficulties. I could go on and on in an in-depth analysis of this game, but I will keep it short and simple: if you want a good story and challenge, Ys Origin is your game.

Posted: July 31, 2013
												If you enjoy playing action role-playing games (particularly those from Japan), Ys Origin is a solid investment.  At first, the level designs and monsters were fairly basic, but this is not so much of an issue as you progress higher up the tower.  The amount of variety in the demon designs and floor designs later on isn't spectacular, but keep in mind this is all going on inside of a tower.  The bosses--I would say--are the only exception.  The level and skill system revolve around finding new equipment and gems.  Although simple in design, there is just enough variety to keep you interested.  The story itself is alright (at least to the point where I am at...), and the characters aren't too bad.  You won't be interacting with them too much anyway.  In order to improve your character's own abilities and the abilities of some of your weapons and other equipment, the game allows players to cash in the SP dropped by defeated demons.  This SP is cashed in at the game's Goddess statues, which also serve as save points.  Generally, the distance between these save points is just the "right" distance.  If you don't know what difficulty to play at, I would recommend the "normal" difficulty setting.  Normal might seem too easy at first, but the game becomes significantly harder later on.  However, action RPG veterans will likely want to bump up the difficulty a notch or two.  If not at the normal price, then consider adding Ys Origin to your Steam library the next time the game is on sale.

												Ys series in general are not very long and their challenge level is fair with minimal grinding required. This one is a bit of exception in length and challenge, but not as negative aspects. While the length for one character is the average of any other Ys, the replay value lies in the fact there are THREE characters in total, each one with their own play style and emphasizing one aspect or another. And the story also changes itself, showing things that happens with that character while it was not on camera to another, or sometimes fate itself will twist and a whole new situation will unfold.For those seeking for challenge, bosses and enemies can be blazed through in easier difficulties, grinded in average ones, or skillfully fought in later difficulties. I could go on and on in an in-depth analysis of this game, but I will keep it short and simple: if you want a good story and challenge, Ys Origin is your game.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												"Ys Origin is a Japanese action role-playing game developed and published by Nihon Falcom for Microsoft Windows in 2006." (Wikipedia, November 2013)I've played this RPG for 45 hours on the hardest of the 5 difficulties (nightmare, hard, normal, easy, very easy) with "Hugo" (1 of 3 characters) and completed it by level 52. I found the story to be a run-of-the-mill "good guy wants power, turns evil temporarily, and repents through the power of friendship/love". I'm generally not the type of guy to delve into, and enjoy, the story of a game very much anyways, so I didn't mind it. In fact, considering that I look for "great gameplay" in games, and what type of gameplay I'll tend to go for, I would practically expect a story to be "the usual" in a game (not to say I haven't enjoyed original stories). I don't know how the story goes with the other 2 characters, since I haven't played them yet.This game, played with a top-down camera angle, plays kinda like a shooter when Hugo is the chosen character, as his attacks revolve around shooting magic missiles straight ahead of him. After a quick test run, the other 2 characters appear to revolve around close-range melee combat. On the hardest difficulty level, the bosses offer such a challenge that you'll find yourself grinding a lot, just to gain that extra level or two and be able to defeat the boss at all (and even then, your battle strategy better be near perfect). This game has some simple puzzle-solving, if you can even call it that. You'll find yourself having to press buttons, defeat certain enemies, obtain and use items/skills, and so on. I did enjoy the challenging gameplay, but it would get frustrating at times with bosses, and also 1 time with a certain enemy that can practically insta-kill you (but that you'll still have to deal with). The only thing to do there is keep looking around for equipment and the like, and grind in special spots to gain levels.If you want to know how nice the graphics look, just "You-Google-Tube" some gameplay footage on the game. And while you're at it, check out the soundtrack for it as well. It's pretty awesome. As of this post, the game is normally $19.99 USD on Steam and I'd say it's worth the price if you love to spend many hours on a challenging "battle-grind" RPG. If it turns-out that you love the game, then you may also love "Ys: The Oath in Felghana", which follows a similar gaming style. You may want to avoid Ys I & II though, which has your main attack revolve around ramming into enemies (like in Hydlide), which ruins any sense of "gameplay" (at least in my opinion).

												Can't really place why Origin stands out as my favourite in the Ys series, but it just does. The gameplay is fast, fun and fluid and the boss fights are challenging yet rewarding. Youre standard enemies are easy to kill and don't provide much of a challenge at all, they really only exist to grind if you want to when the bosses start kicking you♥♥♥♥♥ Three main story characters, all of which have unique fighting styles and individual stories, really help to make the game feel whole.On their own, the stories are jagged and a bit weak. Posted: February 28, 2015
												After playing Ys I + 2, and Ys: Oath in Felghana, I had high expectations for this one. They were met and exceeded.* Great music * Great gameplay - boss fights are amazing, and beating a boss on the higher difficulty settings is really satisfying* Responsive controls - if you fail at the game, it's on you, not the controller* Three different characters to play as, with different styles and viewpoints of the game's events* Difficulty options are appreciated. I did a hard playthrough and a couple of easy playthoughs because I was a little more interested in story things than brutal gameplayI'll probably come back to this one later for a nightmare difficulty playthrough. Or three.Only real downside is the game setting and pacing is pretty much the same for all of the characters, so the third playthrough started to wear on me a bit. In hindsight, I shouldn't have played through it 3x without any other games mixed in to keep things fresh.Nice Bonus - the .ogg files work with my mp3 player, unlike Oath of Felghana's.

Posted: July 4, 2015
												Good combat and a fair story are the strong points of this game.Extremely linear progression and the fact that you are confined to a tower for pretty much all of the play are it's cons.You play as three characters (a playthrough for each, one being unlockable after finishing with one of the other two) through the story mode to unravel their story as they ascend the demon tower, battling monsters and large bosses along the way. The story itself is fair, with some expected plot twists (and some not so expected) but doesn't have that much in the funny side. Everyone seems more into serious business mode. So if you want something with laughs this isn't really the game.Combat is real time, meaning that for the most part your skill at dodging attacks will determine your success, mostly in the harder difficulties. You don't get healing items nor healing magic either but some enemies drop use-on-pickup items. Some heal, some boost a stat for a time, and there's also currency drops you use to buy upgrades. A gripe I have is that the items and currency are dropped pretty much everywhere when killing monsters and because they disappear over time, you sometimes have to choose between clearing the room or pausing to run around to grab the spread items. Each character has basic attacks, including jump and jump attacks, and obtain magic items through the game that allow them to use special abilities used mainly for battle but are sometimes needed to get past certain parts of the game. There's no puzzles here either so most of the time you are either in combat or reading the story.Speaking of sounds, there's no voice acting here and the music is pretty much midi based. In fact all sounds remind me of the final 16 bit (SuperNES) to early 32 bit (PS1) era games so don't expect a John Williams score here.Visuals are the same. Characters and common enemies are all sprite based(they do have beautiful portraits), while the stage and bosses use very low polygon models, akin to PSP games. Sprites are drawn in the chibi style while portraits use the usual serious anime way. The one complain I have about the visuals is that the whole game takes place in a tower where all rooms are similar in terms of textures and such, only changing their color every few stages. Sure, no room is the same and there's plenty of enemies to get you busy, but I myself like variety of backdrops and open spaces. Then again hard to do when the premise of the game is to explore a big round demon tower.Overall it's a good game I can recommend to throw yourself back with a simple yet effective gameplay, simple visuals that while similar, don't completely bore in my opinion, and a good story to boot.

Posted: November 8, 2015
Ys OriginStoryYou follow the story of Yunica Tovah, Hugo Fact & The Claw and the events that takes place 700 years before Ys 1 and tells the back-story of Ys, Darm Tower, the Black Pearl, the twin goddesses, and the six priests.GameplayYou have the option to play as one of two characters, a third character is playable after completing the game once with either Yunica or hugo on any difficulty level, on five different difficulty levels ranging from very easy to nightmare which is sure to give all types of gamers a challenge. The game can get a bit grindy at times but overall the gameplay is fast and exciting with allot of button smashing that makes you feel like you just went a round at the gym.After you played through with all the characters I suggest you give Time Attack a try which is a mode where you only fight the bosses and try to beat them as fast as possible. The replay value of the story mode is not that great if you ask me, unless you haven't played it in a good while.Unlike Ys 1 & 2 where you run into enemies to damage them you now have a Action/Attack button, as well as a Jump button, which is a nice change from the bump system.SoundThe soundtrack is absolutely amazing which is no surprise since the Ys series always had a great soundtrack.GraphicsThe graphics looks nice on newer as well as a bit older PC's and gives you that RPG feeling.Final wordsAll in all Ys Origin is a great game you shouldn't miss if you are a A-RPG fan.+Boss fights are great and gets your blood pumping.+Amazing soundtrack.-Can get a bit grindy.Score: 8/10

Posted: December 28, 2016
												Ys Origin is a highly entertaining ARPG that let's you slice, smash, and burn your ways through demons floor after floor. The first Ys game as far as the lore background of the series is concerned, Ys Origin takes place several hundred years before the events of the first game and portrays several issues that have only been mentioned by name or entirely left in the dark in the previous Ys games.In the game's main mode, you can choose one of two (later three) heroes to reach the top of a mysterious demonic tower in pursuit of two goddesses. Though the game mechanics and the tower itself are identical for all characters, each plays a bit differently - Yunica is a fairly tough melee fighter with useful area of attack special abilities, while Hugo is a range-centric mage with a strong standard attack and largely defensive skills. The third, unlockable character finally is goes full rogue, being capable of dishing out lots of damage in close combat yet also sharing Hugo's fragile nature.Unless you plan to start in nightmare mode right away, the difficulty of the game generally is reasonable. Trash mobs typically do not pose much of a challenge unless you are seriously underleveled (and this problem can be solved with a bit of grinding), but the boss fights more than often will take you multiple tries to find the right strategy. Fortunately, this rarely becomes frustrating, not to the least because the game's fantastic soundtrack is one hell of a motivating factor.Story-wise, the game is okay-ish. Though Ys Origins does answer lots of questions propped open by the earlier games, two of the three playable character follow the old "THE POWER OF FRIENDSHIP(tm)" plotline, with daddy issues galore. Ys Origins certainly has its moments, the plot will become fairly predictable if you've ever played a JRPG beforeDespite of its minor flaws, Ys Origin still is a more than decent ARPG and one of the better parts in the Ys series.
